title: Approaches to concurrency
heading: ROOT
text:
There are 2 approaches to concurrency

so assume you want to split your code into two threads , you can do one of the following (The 2 programmers and separate/same office example): 

1. Put the 2 threads in one process (Faster and easier)
2. make 2 processes each have 1 of the threads (More safe)

---


For the first approach, this is like 2 employees work on the same project from the same office but they share a single copy of the tools and documents which is faster but can induce conflicts 

![[conc4 1.png|200]]
The threads communicate together using shared memory, and this is the favored approach in  C++

Advantages :
- Low overhead for communication
- Faster
Disadvantages :
- Less safe 



For the second approach, this is like 2 employees working on the same project but in a separate office.  each one has his own tools and documents which is more safe but there is an overhead in the communication.
![[conc3.png|200]]
The processes communicate together using [[interprocess communication]]

Advantages :
- Safe
- Can run each process on a different machines that are connected over a network or on the same machine

Disadvantages:
- Complicated to set up
- Slower
- More resources Because each process will consume it's own resources by the OS

title: auth flow vulnerability
heading: Visualization of the Authentication Flaw in `utility-invoices`
text: This document contains diagrams to explain the security vulnerability in the authentication flow between the `utility-invoices-frontend` and its backend.

title: auth flow vulnerability
heading: How It Should Work (A Secure Flow)
text:
This is the standard, secure way to connect a frontend to a backend. The key step is **#6**, where the backend validates the token it receives from the frontend before processing the request. ```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant User participant Frontend participant Google participant Backend User->>Frontend: 1. Clicks "Login" Frontend->>Google: 2. Redirects for login Google-->>Frontend: 3. Returns with a secure Token after successful login User->>Frontend: 4. Clicks "Generate Analysis" Frontend->>Backend: 5. Sends API Request + "Authorization: Bearer [Token]" activate Backend Backend->>Backend: 6. **VERIFIES TOKEN**
Is it valid? Is the user authorized? Note right of Backend: If token is invalid, REJECT request. Backend-->>Frontend: 7. Request is valid, process it and return results deactivate Backend ``` ---

title: auth flow vulnerability
heading: How It Currently Works (The Insecure Flow)
text:
This diagram shows the actual, insecure implementation. The backend **never checks for a token (Step #5 and #8)**. This allows an attacker to completely bypass the frontend login and send requests directly to the backend (Step #7). ```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant User participant Attacker participant Frontend participant Google participant Backend %% Legitimate User Flow User->>Frontend: 1. Clicks "Login" Frontend->>Google: 2. User logs in, Frontend gets a Token Note right of Frontend: Token is received but NOT sent to the backend! User->>Frontend: 3. Clicks "Generate Analysis" Frontend->>Backend: 4. Sends API Request (with NO token) activate Backend Backend->>Backend: 5. **NO TOKEN VERIFICATION!**
Processes the request immediately. Backend-->>Frontend: 6. Returns results deactivate Backend %% Attacker's Path Attacker->>Backend: 7. Sends API Request directly to backend URL (NO login, NO token needed) activate Backend Backend->>Backend: 8. **NO TOKEN VERIFICATION!**
Processes the attacker's request. Backend-->>Attacker: 9. Returns results to attacker deactivate Backend ```

title: C++  most vexing parse
heading: ROOT
text:
The C++ most vexing parse is a syntax ambiguity that leads the compiler to misinterpret the  the syntax of an object declaration as a function declaration:

example :
```cpp
Myclass obj(Myclass())
```

Developer intent : declare an object of Myclass and initialize it with a temporary Myclass object

title: C++ Program life time
heading: ROOT
text:
a program lifetime is determined by the main function, not whether there are any threads running.

that's why when you [[detaching threads]] from main thread(in the main function), the program will terminate when the main thread finishes and will force terminate all other threads, detached or not .

heading: ROOT
text:
**What kinds of software projects have you worked on before? Which operating systems, development environments, languages, databases??**

I’ve worked on many software projects, both personal projects and professional ones. the majority of the professional projects are in the automotive domain, but I’ve also worked on other non automotive projects. I've worked on projects with different scales, from a single developer projects to projects with hundreds of developers and contributors :  

| Project                                                    | Programming language and tools                                 | Development environment        | deployment OS           |
| ---------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------ | ----------------------- |
| Farm management system                                     | C                                                              | Windows, ATML studio           | Baremetal               |
| ASUSAR                                                     | C                                                              | Windows, Code composer studio  | Baremetal               |
| Driver Monitoring system for Renault                       | C++, Python, Bash, Make, CMake, Json, Task.yml, Jenkins        | Linux/WSL , Vscode, VectorCAST | QNX (unix based)        |
| Autonomous Parking for BMW                                 | C, C++, Python, Bazel, Make, CMake, Json, Batch files, Jenkins | Windows, Vscode, VectorCAST    | QNX (unix based)        |
| DAS functional requirements testing                        | C++, QT                                                        | Windows, DASTE                 | Windows                 |

| GLIOMA MDC 2025                                            | Python, ML, DL                                                 | WSL, Vscode                    | WSL(Ubuntu)             |
| Live transport network monitor (personal project)(ongoing) | C++, Conan, Ninja, Cmake                                       | WSL, Vscode                    | Windows/WSL(Ubuntu)     |
| Multiservice Backend (personal project)                    | Python, FastAPI, Docker, Terraform, AWS, GitLab                | WSL, Vscode                    | Linux on cloud (Ubuntu) |
|                                                            |                                                                |                                |                         |



---
**Would you describe yourself as a high quality coder? Why?**

Absolutely, because whenever I work on a project, I spend good amount of my time establishing best practices and optimizing the code I've written. One example is in the last project I've worked on -Driver monitoring system-, I've created a coding guidelines document for other developers in the project to maintain a clean, readable and efficient code base. We currently adhere to this document when doing code reviews.

---
**Would you describe yourself as an architect of resilient software? If so, why, and in which sorts of applications?**

Yes. Although I haven't been involved in many arc

title: Canonical written interview
heading: ROOT
text:
when doing code reviews.

---
**Would you describe yourself as an architect of resilient software? If so, why, and in which sorts of applications?**

Yes. Although I haven't been involved in many architecture activities, I am always interested in how big software is composed and designed from the ground up. I have also designed many components (LLD) which were used in safety-critical applications like an error handler in an autonomous parking application, I've also participated in many testing activities (unit, integration, validation) which changed the way how I write software ; i.e. with testing in mind.

---
**Outline your thoughts on open source software development. What is important to get right in open source projects? What open source projects have you worked on? Have you been an open source maintainer, on which projects, and what was your role?**

I see open source as a cornerstone to modern software development. Many low income industries thrive on it, on the other hand it enables developers from all around the world to collectively build, review and improve software in a transparent and inclusive way.

I think the most important thing to get right in open source projects is generally "organization", and this includes a well-written documentation, a clear contribution guide line, Issue tracking and labels. Other important parts are maintainers availability and licensing.

I worked on ASUSAR as a contributor, which is an open source project to implement the AUTOSAR stack used in the automotive domain to write a hardware-abstracted code.

I have been an integrator and maintainer for the "Driver Monitoring System" project mentioned earlier in my responses, while it is not an open source project per se, I do the exact activities of a maintainer .

---
**How compr

title: Canonical written interview
heading: ROOT
text:
and maintainer for the "Driver Monitoring System" project mentioned earlier in my responses, while it is not an open source project per se, I do the exact activities of a maintainer .

---
**How comprehensive would you say your knowledge of a Linux distribution is, from the kernel up? How familiar are you with low-level system architecture, runtimes and Linux distro packaging? How have you gained this knowledge?**

I’d describe my knowledge of Linux as moderate and growing, with solid experience across user space, application debugging, and some system-level debugging. I’m familiar with the layers that make up a Linux distribution — from the kernel, init systems, libraries, system calls, and userland tools, up to package management and deployment. I have specific experience in ubuntu distributions as a user, as it was the development environment for some of the projects I've worked on like mentioned earlier.

I've gained this knowledge through 
1. professional experience where I worked on linux systems as development/deployment environment and unix-based systems as deployment environment
2. Embedded Linux bootcamp by Hazem Khaled

---
**Outline your thoughts on performance in software engineering. How do you ensure that your product is fast?**

Performance in software engineering is a relative measure and depends on the runtime requirements of the application, while a better performance is always desirable it can be on the expense of other factors, so it's important to know the limits of your system and design a performant system with a safety margin from what is initially required. 

How to ensure a product is fast :

1.  Design for efficiency : choosing the right algorithms and data structures from the start and use language specific best practices, making use of conc

title: Canonical written interview
heading: ROOT
text:
required. 

How to ensure a product is fast :

1.  Design for efficiency : choosing the right algorithms and data structures from the start and use language specific best practices, making use of concurrency is also almost always beneficial. 
2.  Measure and profile : using tools like showmem, htop, time and valgrind to analyze my software  and define bottlenecks.
---
**Outline your thoughts on quality in software development. What practices are most effective in software teams to drive improvements in quality?**

For me quality in software development is the set of practices and and processes that were followed during writing the software and not just the end result. a certain practice that is most effective to drive improvement in quality is software testing on all levels (unit, integration, validation), having the right testing activities is guaranteed to increase quality of the software. CI/CD best practices and having a mature CI/CD pipelines almost always also increase software quality from my experience. 

---

title: Canonical written interview
heading: **Multipass related technologies**
text:
---


**Describe your experience with C++.  Which standard(s) are you familiar with? What are some features you use regularly?**

Like indicated in my projects, I've worked on many C++ projects. However I would stay humble and say that C++ is a huge language and I am still to master it; but according to my colleagues I have a good understanding of C++ than the average software engineer in my company.

I am familiar with the C++11, C++14  and parts of the C++17 standards. 
Some features I use are :
- Memory management : using RAII, smart pointers, std::move 
- Type safety : enum class, auto
- Standard library utilities :  std::optional, std::variant
- Standard library data structures and containers : std::map, std::unordered_map, std::set 
- Multithreading : std::atomic, thread, std::mutex


---

**How do you measure and minimize the resource footprint of your C++ applications?**

==RAM==
I measure the memory consumption (RAM) using showmem utility in QNX which shows the total RAM consumed by a certain application (process) which also includes the mapped memory from shared libraries.
 I minimize the RAM footprint by avoiding common RAM-wasting patterns like :
- Using smallest possible data types for variables
- Avoid Large global/static variables
- Detecting memory leaks and eliminating it
- Remove unused data
- Releasing memory when done processing 
- Avoid unbounded Buffers or Caches

==ROM==
I measure the ROM footprint by just checking the application size on desk through the file system.
I minimize ROM by using minimum size release toolchains if available and using the strip utility(or similar) available in the SDK to remove debugging/unused symbols in production.

==CPU Load==
I measure the CPU load using Top command in linux (hogs in QNX) to determine my process cp

title: Canonical written interview
heading: **Multipass related technologies**
text:
trip utility(or similar) available in the SDK to remove debugging/unused symbols in production.

==CPU Load==
I measure the CPU load using Top command in linux (hogs in QNX) to determine my process cpu load and check the thread states, CPU load can be optimized by:
- Using concurrency in the design phase
- Removing busy waits and polling loops
- Optimize algorithms and account for time complexity
- Avoid context switching if possible

---
**What hypervisors are you familiar with on Windows and Linux? Describe your experience with these.**

I am familiar with Vbox, QEMU and Docker. 

- I used VBox to learn linux and install virtual linux machines .
- I used QEMU in professional setting as we used it to test our embedded applications that was supposed to run on QNX when actual hardware is not available.
- I used docker in the multiservice project mentioned earlier to containerize the services .
---
**Describe your development experience on Linux, Windows, and/or macOS.**

Like mentioned in previous responses -specifically my first response- I have good development experience on both Linux and Windows. 
I don't have development experience on macOS but willing to learn.

---
**Describe your level of understanding of networking, especially virtual networking on Windows, macOS and Linux.**

I would describe my level of networking as good, I am comfortable with the OSI model and the TCP/IP stack, I've written TCP/UDP tests, configured static IPs on windows and Linux. I can also analyze network packets using Wireshark. 
I have no deep experience in virtual networking.

---

title: Canonical written interview
heading: **Education**
text:
---


**How did you rank in your final year of high school in mathematics? Were you a top student? On what basis would you say that?**

In the final year of high school -called thanweya a'ma in Egypt- I ranked 2nd overall on class, out of ~100 student enlisted in my school. I also ranked top 0.05% on the whole country which qualified me to be admitted to Ainshams university, the top engineering university in Egypt . 
In mathematics specifically, there was no ranking done by school or country, but I got full marks in all mathematics branches (algebra, geometry, statics) and was 2 marks short from a full mark in dynamics. 
The basis on what I say this is school ranking, the 1st on class got an overall mark of 98.5%, He's currently doing PhD in Italy and is still a friend of mine, while I got an overall mark of 98.2%, I can try to get a transcript upon request. 

---

**How did you rank in your final year of high school, in your home language? Were you a top student? On what basis would you say that?**

Please refer to the last answer, there was also no specific ranking based on home language subject, but again I ranked 2nd overall on my school in high school . I was generally very well spoken in Arabic (home language) and I participated in many domestic Arabic speaking competitions. I also was the main speaker in the school morning radio due to my linguistic eloquence .


---

**Please state your high school graduation results or university entrance results, and explain the grading system used. For example, in the US, you might give your SAT or ACT scores. In Germany, you might give your scores out of a grading system of 1-5, with 1 being the best.**

In Egypt, high school graduation result is what qualifies for the university entrance, there are no other Exams like SAT o

title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: 1. Application Overview
text:
The Pricing Analysis application is a powerful tool designed for purchasing departments to analyze product costs, identify price variations, and forecast prices for new or existing products. It combines data analysis, machine learning, and generative AI to provide actionable insights from purchasing data.

  

The application is composed of two main services:

chunk_id: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md::s2::c0
rel_path: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md
title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: Frontend
text:
A modern, user-friendly web interface built with **React**, **Vite**, and **TypeScript**. It uses **Tailwind CSS** and **shadcn/ui** for a polished and responsive design.

  

-   **Purpose**: To provide an intuitive, step-by-step wizard for users to configure and run pricing analyses.

-   **Key Features**:

    -   Two distinct analysis workflows: **Price Forecasting** and **Segment Database Analysis**.

    -   Dynamic fetching of datasets and their columns from the backend.

    -   Interactive controls for selecting features, setting priorities, and configuring analysis parameters.

    -   Clear visualization of results, including AI-generated reports and sortable data tables.

    -   User authentication via Google Login.

chunk_id: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md::s3::c0
rel_path: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md
title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: Backend
text:
A robust API service built with **Python** and **FastAPI**. It serves as the engine for all data processing and analysis.

  

-   **Purpose**: To handle the complex logic of data retrieval, analysis, machine learning, and AI-powered report generation.

-   **Key Technologies**:

    -   **FastAPI**: For building high-performance APIs.

    -   **Pandas**: For data manipulation and analysis.

    -   **PyCaret** & **XGBoost**: For creating and training machine learning models to predict prices.

    -   **Google Drive & Sheets API**: To access datasets and currency information.

    -   **Generative AI Integration**: Connects to a Large Language Model (LLM) to generate qualitative reports, summaries, and justifications for the quantitative analysis.

chunk_id: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md::s4::c0
rel_path: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md
title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: API Endpoints
text:
The backend exposes the following RESTful API endpoints, all prefixed with `/pp/analysis/api/v1alpha1`.

  

| Method | Path | Description |

| :--- | :--- | :--- |

| `GET` | `/health` | Health check endpoint to verify if the service is running. |

| `GET` | `/collections` | Lists all available datasets (CSV files) from the configured Google Drive folder. |

| `GET` | `/column-names` | Lists all accepted columns and their types (numerical/categorical) for a given dataset. |

| `GET` | `/target-column` | Returns the recommended target (price) column(s) for a given dataset. |

| `GET` | `/currencies` | Returns a list of all supported currencies and their codes. |

| `GET` | `/currency_rates` | Fetches exchange rates from Google Sheets for a given reference currency. |

| `POST` | `/full-analysis` | Runs a comprehensive analysis on an entire dataset to find price variations. |

| `POST` | `/targeted-analysis` | Runs a targeted analysis to find items similar to a user-defined data point. |

| `POST` | `/final-target-report` | Generates a price forecast for a target item using a machine learning model and provides an AI-powered justification. |

  
  

---

title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: A. Price Forecasting Sequence
text:
This diagram shows the interaction between components during a Price Forecasting analysis.

  

```mermaid

sequenceDiagram

    participant User

    participant Frontend (React)

    participant Backend (FastAPI)

    participant Google Drive

    participant ML Service (PyCaret)

    participant LLM Service

  

    User->>Frontend: Selects Dataset

    Frontend->>Backend: GET /collections

    Backend->>Google Drive: List files

    Google Drive-->>Backend: File list

    Backend-->>Frontend: JSON [datasets]

    User->>Frontend: Selects Cost Drivers & Target Item Specs

    User->>Frontend: Configures Exchange Rates

    User->>Frontend: Clicks "Run Analysis"

    Frontend->>Backend: POST /final-target-report (with config)

    Backend->>Google Drive: Download CSV file

    Google Drive-->>Backend: File content

    Backend->>Backend: Perform currency conversion

    Backend->>ML Service (PyCaret): Train regression model on data

    ML Service (PyCaret)-->>Backend: Trained model

    Backend->>ML Service (PyCaret): Predict price for target item

    ML Service (PyCaret)-->>Backend: Predicted Price

    Backend->>Backend: Find similar items (Gower Distance)

    Backend->>LLM Service: POST /generate (Prompt + Predicted Price + Similar Items)

    LLM Service-->>Backend: AI-generated report & confidence score

    Backend-->>Frontend: JSON { ai_insights, cost, executionTime }

    Frontend->>User: Display formatted results

```

heading: 4. Deployment
text: Both the frontend and backend are designed to be deployed as Docker containers.

chunk_id: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md::s11::c0
rel_path: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md
title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: Backend (`pricing-analysis-backend`)
text:
-   **`Dockerfile`**: A multi-stage Dockerfile that uses `poetry` to install dependencies in a builder stage and creates a lean final image running the `fastapi` server.

-   **`pyproject.toml`**: Defines all Python dependencies. It's crucial for `poetry` to resolve and install the correct packages.

-   **`.env` file (at runtime)**: This file is critical and must contain all necessary environment variables defined in `config/settings.py`, such as:

    -   `GCP_PROJECT_ID`

    -   `FRAMEWORK_SERVICE_ACCOUNT` and other auth-related IDs.

    -   `DRIVE_FOLDER_ID` to specify where the datasets are located in Google Drive.

-   **Google Cloud Credentials**: The container expects a service account key file to be mounted at `/secrets/secrets.json`. This is used for authenticating with Google Drive and other GCP services.

chunk_id: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md::s12::c0
rel_path: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md
title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: Frontend (`pricing-analysis-frontend`)
text:
-   **`docker/Dockerfile`**: A multi-stage Dockerfile.

    1.  The `build` stage uses a `node` image to install dependencies with `pnpm` and build the React application using `vite build`.

    2.  The `prod` stage uses a lightweight `nginx` image and copies the built static assets into the web server directory.

-   **`config/nginx.conf`**: A custom Nginx configuration. This is a critical file for deployment.

    -   It configures Nginx to serve the React application as a Single-Page Application (SPA).

    -   It correctly handles client-side routing by redirecting all non-asset requests to `index.html`.

    -   It sets the base path for the application, with specific `location` blocks for `/price-analysis/price-forecasting` and `/price-analysis/segment-analysis`. Any changes to the application's base URL or routes would require updating this file.

-   **`.env.*` files**: Vite uses these files to manage environment variables. The `VITE_API_BASE_URL` must be set correctly to point to the deployed backend API for the specific environment (dev, acp, etc.).

  

---

chunk_id: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md::s13::c0
rel_path: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md
title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: 5. Q&A and Business Logic
text:
This section clarifies common scenarios and the underlying logic of the application.

  

**Q1: What happens if my dataset contains prices in multiple currencies?**

**A:** The application is designed to handle this. After you select your dataset and cost drivers, you will be prompted to select a single "Reference Currency". The application then fetches the latest exchange rates from a Google Sheet and asks you to confirm or edit them. All prices in your dataset are then normalized to this single reference currency before any analysis is performed. This ensures that all comparisons and predictions are made on a level playing field.

  

**Q2: How does "Price Forecasting" actually work? What's the difference between the ML model and the AI?**

**A:** Price Forecasting uses a two-pronged approach:

1.  **Machine Learning (ML) Prediction**: It first trains a regression model on the entire historical dataset using PyCaret. This model learns the statistical relationships between the "cost drivers" (features) and the price. It then uses this model to generate a purely quantitative price prediction for your target item.

2.  **AI-Powered Justification**: It then finds the most factually similar items from the dataset using a Gower distance metric. The predicted price, your target item's specs, and the list of these similar items are all sent to a Large Language Model (LLM). The AI's job is to act as a strategist, analyze this information, and write a report that justifies the predicted price, explains a confidence score, and highlights key differences between your target item and existing ones.

  

**Q3: In Price Forecasting, what is the difference between "I have all cost drivers" and "I want to forecast on some"?**

**A:**

-   **"I have all cost drivers"**: Choose this opt

chunk_id: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md::s13::c1
rel_path: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md
title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application
heading: 5. Q&A and Business Logic
text:
existing ones.

  

**Q3: In Price Forecasting, what is the difference between "I have all cost drivers" and "I want to forecast on some"?**

**A:**

-   **"I have all cost drivers"**: Choose this option when you want a price prediction for a **new item** that is not in the dataset. The application will present you with input fields for *all* the required features (cost drivers) for that product type, as this is necessary for the machine learning model to make an accurate prediction.

-   **"I want to forecast on some"**: Choose this when you want to analyze an **existing item or a group of similar items** within the dataset. You only need to provide a few key specifications. The application will then find all items that match those specs and provide a statistical summary and AI analysis, without running a predictive model.

  

**Q4: What does "Gower Distance" mean when finding similar items?**

**A:** Gower Distance is a metric used to measure the dissimilarity between two data points that have a mix of numerical (like `Length` or `Mass`) and categorical (like `Raw Material` or `Supplier`) features. Unlike simple Euclidean distance, it can handle different data types intelligently. In this app, it allows the backend to find the "closest" or "most similar" items in the dataset to your target item, even if no exact match exists across all attributes.

  

**Q5: Why are there no results in the "Multiple Grouping" tab during a Segment Analysis?**

**A:** This typically happens for one of two reasons:

1.  **No Groups Found**: Based on the columns you selected for grouping, every single item in the dataset was unique. Therefore, no groups with more than one item could be formed.

2.  **No Significant Variation**: Groups were formed, but none of them had a price variation (

rel_path: 00_inbox/Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application.md
title: Comprehensive Guide to the Pricing Analysis Application

text:
ery single item in the dataset was unique. Therefore, no groups with more than one item could be formed.

2.  **No Significant Variation**: Groups were formed, but none of them had a price variation (standard deviation) high enough to meet the "variation threshold" defined in the analysis.

In either case, you should check the **"Single Items"** tab, which will list all the items that did not fit into a multi-item group.

title: cookies (stateful) vs tokens (stateless)
heading: ROOT
text:
```pgsql
          🟦 Stateful (Cookies)                     🟩 Stateless (Tokens)

   ┌───────────────┐                          ┌───────────────┐
   │   Client      │                          │   Client      │
   │ (Browser)     │                          │ (App/Browser) │
   └─────┬─────────┘                          └─────┬─────────┘
         │   1. Login Request                        │   1. Login Request
         ▼                                           ▼
   ┌───────────────┐                          ┌───────────────┐
   │   Server      │                          │   Server      │
   └─────┬─────────┘                          └─────┬─────────┘
         │   2. Create session in DB                │   2. Generate JWT
         │      (session_id → user data)            │      (signed token)
         │                                          │
         ▼                                          ▼
   ┌───────────────┐                          ┌───────────────┐
   │   Client      │                          │   Client      │
   │ Stores Cookie │                          │ Stores Token  │
   └─────┬─────────┘                          └─────┬─────────┘
         │   3. Send cookie (session_id)            │   3. Send token in
         │      with every request                  │      Authorization header
         ▼                                          ▼
   ┌───────────────┐                          ┌───────────────┐
   │   Server      │                          │   Server      │
   │ Looks up DB   │                          │ Just verifies │
   │ session state │                          │ token validity│
   └───────────────┘                          └───────────────┘


```

title: Docx_generation_service
heading: ROOT
text:
is the one responsible for generating the docx document, 
ProdVal backend flow is as follows 
1. User request comes to Light/power/brain plant generator
2. The generator prepares a series of prompts based on input specification
3. It sends these prompts to a generative AI service with the input docs
4. The AI service returns the generated test plans in a markdown format
5. The markdown is then passed to the docx_generation_service to be converted to a .docx file

title: Dynamic memory allocation C++
heading: Dynamically allocated memory
text:
Allocating memory using the new operator, memory gets allocated in the heap and is reserved for the application till it is deleted 
```cpp
int * int_ptr {new (std::nothrow) int {10}} ;

```
---

title: Dynamic memory allocation C++
heading: Deleting dynamically allocated memory
text:
Deleting dynamically allocated memory is to free the memory from the application and give it back to the OS so it is able to reuse it or assign it to another application.

After deleting the dynamically allocated memory, the pointer that used to point to this memory will still persist and will still point to the same memory location and will still be referenceable by the application and is called [[dangling pointer]]. if we try to dereference this pointer without reassigning it will cause undefined behavior and it may lead to [[Segmentation fault C++ | Segmentation fault]] 

Also the destructor of the object is called if the pointer was pointing to an object. This allows for any necessary cleanup, such as releasing resources or performing other cleanup tasks.
To delete a dynamically allocated memory you have to use the delete operator

example :
```cpp
int * int_ptr {new (std::nothrow) int {50}} ;

delete int_ptr; // give the memory back to the OS, note that the variable int_ptr itself still exists and still points to the same memory location, now int_ptr is a dangling pointer

cout << *int_ptr << endl ; // undefined behaviour
int_ptr = nullptr; // reassign int_ptr to nullptr

```

---
{{References}} 

https://www.learncpp.com/cpp-tutorial/dynamic-memory-allocation-with-new-and-delete/

title: dynamically typed programming language
heading: ROOT
text:
A dynamically typed programming language is a programming language that u can change it's variables types at runtime, i.e the types are checked at runtime rather than at compile time. Therefore they are not fixed  
```js 
let x = 42;      // number
x = "Ahmed";     // now a string, still valid
```

While a statically typed language like C++, the type have to be defined at compile time and can't be changed at runtime 
```cpp
int x = 42;
x = "Ahmed"; // ❌ compile-time error

```


So dynamic typing = no static type checking. 

Also worth noting that the variable type is determined by what value type it is currently holding because [[javascript has value data types and not variables data types ]]

heading: Physical layer
text:

[[ethernet_physical_layer]]

title: Ethernet training
heading: Configurations :
text:
1. **Media protocol**
	- Wifi 
	- RJ45 (el ethernet cable bta3 el telephone ) 
		- 10 base tx
		- 100 base tx : ( 100 Mbit/sec), base = baseband signal, t = twisted pair, x= type of encoding (4 selkat)
		- 1000 base tx (8 selkat)
	- Fiber
		- 1000 base fx
	- BroadReach (selkteen)(twisted pair)
		- 100 Base T1 
2. **half duplex**  - full duplex 
3. **Auto negotiation** : if a physical layer has multiple protocols (100 base tx, 1000 base t,etc)
	You can set the auto negotiation option to adapt based on the other node, garab wa7da wa7da l7ad ma el node tlink ma3ah

4. **Phy address** : is address used to differentiate between 2 physical layers for the same ethernet interface that has a uni

 5. skewing effect shift
MII : parallel communication not serial 

MII 
RMII
GMII
RGMII 


you have to know the value of the shift between the rx lines and tx lines in the RGMII to avoid the **Skewing effect** 


Configuration frame : 
start - read - PHY address - reg address - register data 

Homework : 
What is SGMII
Does switch has a MAC ? spanning tree protocol ?

---

title: Ethernet training
heading: Data -Link layer : mac address (switching) (Layer 2)
text:
MTU : maximum transmission unit (1400 - 1500 ) 
MTU = Number - 26 (Preamble + SDF + SourceAddress + DestinationAddress etc)

Implements 
- Frame Synchronization (adding a header and a footer)
- Error control (CRC)
- Hardware addressing (Mac address)(configured at initialization or OTP)

 uses mac address for communication, it's enough if we want to communicate with devices on the same LAN, we can build a network on this layer
why don't we use the data link layer and physical layer only in automotive ?

Old frame(802.3) supports the unicast, by using SA and DA
Old frame supports broadcast using FFFF in the Destination address
old frame supports multicast using reserved address

new MAC frame (802.1q)  supports a new concept called  VLAN
New frame supports multicast using VLAN

TPID (Tag protocol identifier) 0x8100 is used to identify that the frame has a  VLAN 

Switch only understands MAC (level 2)

This layer only detects errors but does not give a feedback to the sender 

the "type" bits in the frame determine the above protocol (IP / AVB / etc)

---

title: Ethernet training
heading: Internet layer/Ip layer: Ip address (routing)
text:
ipv4 does not know by default how to talk to  a router, the windows is responsible for talking to the router and that's related to the gateway ip configuration


A router has an Ip address  

routing on the level of routers

TLL : 3adet 3ala kam switch ? 3alshan byb2a configured 3adad mo3ayen lw et5ateto b drop 3alshan el ddos attacks

ICMP is the one that detects the ttl drop


ipv6 doesn't have broadcast, but only have multicast. due to security reasons


ipv6 doesn't use ARP but uses NDP , also for security reasons because ARP  for example doesn't detect duplicates 

---

title: Ethernet training
heading: Application layer
text:
difference between CAN and Ethernet ?
Can is configured in the low layer(Message Ids), ethernet is configured in the application layer (sockets)

---

title: Ethernet training
heading: General notes
text:
- Switch is layer 2 (understands mac only )
- you have to check if the hardware supports the vlan 



---

title: Ethernet training
heading: Transport Layer :
text:
- End to end data transfer 
- Connection oriented - TCP | Connectionless - UDP 

Automotive applications :
Periodic event tends to be UDP (sensors tend to send data periodically ) 
TCP is used for flashing and 
AVB is over layer 2 direct, neither TCP nor UDP 

---
UDP 
- UDP relies on IP for fragmentation
- UDP header does not have IP because IP is in the internet layer 
---
TCP 
 - sequence number == random number used to start a session and indicate a certain session
 - Ack number == random number
 - checksum is mandatory
 - Windows, is the maximum a receiver can receive in one session 


Configurations:
 1. windows
 2. Delayed ack
 3. reply timeout

---

AUTOSAR
Soad : converts packet based tcpip message to pdu based autosar message 

EthSM: opens and closes the low layer, it communicates with COMM 
link states off -> no comm, link states on -> full comm


DOIP :
is optional, you can remove it and connect to DCM directly, it's main purpose is security



---

- what happens if the ID number is generated twice ? A : you are still sending the same frame in the same session 
- When I assign my server IP in the code, how does the ip layer knows the ip address

Execution manifest contains the configurations for the instantiation for a certain application, it is later generated into execution_config.json

Startup config = dependencies to start application

title: export
heading: ROOT
text:
export makes things available to other files

there are two types of exports

title: export
heading: Default exports
text:
``` React

export default func()

```

```
import function_renamed from "./filename"
```

- can be renamed
- only one export is allowed per module
- must use the default keyword when defining the exported function

title: export
heading: Named exports
text:
``` React
export default func()
```


```
import {func} from "./filename"
```

- Cannot be named
- Allows exports per component
- Is the industry standard for exporting hooks and utils

title: export
heading: notes :
text:
component = default export
utils and hooks = named export

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 🧠 MDC Glioma Challenge – CNN Pipeline
text:
This document outlines a robust, critical CNN pipeline for the MDC Glioma Challenge, covering all key stages: preprocessing, model design, training, and postprocessing.

---
save to png to avoid loss

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 1.1. Image Normalization
text:
- Normalize pixel values to [0, 1]
- Standardize using dataset-specific mean and std

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 1.2. Handle Staining & Scanner Variability
text:
- Histogram Matching (target template slide)
- CLAHE for contrast enhancement

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 1.3. Data Augmentation
text:
- Geometric: rotation, flipping, scaling
- Elastic deformation
- Color jittering (brightness, contrast, saturation, hue)

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 1.4. Masking Annotated Regions
text:
- Use JSON files to create binary masks
- Focus model attention on labeled tumor regions

---

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 2.1. Backbone Selection (Pretrained)
text:
- **ResNet50** – good balance between depth & complexity
- **EfficientNet** – lighter, better accuracy/size tradeoff
- **DenseNet** – strong performance on small medical sets

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 2.2. Segmentation Head
text: - U-Net architecture with skip connections for accurate tumor segmentation

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 2.3. Classification Head
text:
- FC layers added after encoder or segmentation output
- Output: tumor type / grade (if labeled)

---

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 3.1. SSL on Unlabeled Data
text:
- Use **SimCLR**, **Model Genesis**, or **MoCo-med**
- Learn generalizable features from all images

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 3.2. Fine-Tuning
text:
- Load SSL-pretrained weights
- Train on labeled data with lower LR

---

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 4.1. Cross-Validation
text: - 5-fold CV to test generalization

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 4.2. Metrics
text:
- **F1 Score**
- **Dice Score**
- **IoU**
- **Precision / Recall**

---

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 5.1. Mask Refinement
text: - Morphological operations: erosion, dilation, opening

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 5.2. Thresholding
text:
- Convert probability map to binary mask using tuned threshold

---

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 6.1. Pseudo-Labeling
text:
- Predict on unlabeled data
- Use confident predictions in training

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 6.2. Consistency Regularization
text:
- Add perturbations to input and force consistent predictions

---

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 7. 🛠️ Implementation Notes
text:
- Frameworks: PyTorch or TensorFlow
- Use `albumentations` for rich augmentations
- Ensure GPU support for 3D or large-scale training
- Track experiments (e.g., with `wandb`)

---

title: Gliomapipeline
heading: 8. ✅ Summary
text:
| Component       | Method / Tool                         |
|----------------|----------------------------------------|
| Normalization   | Histogram Matching, CLAHE              |
| Augmentation    | `albumentations`                       |
| Backbone        | ResNet / DenseNet / EfficientNet       |
| Segmentation    | U-Net                                  |
| Classification  | FC Head                                |
| SSL Pretraining | SimCLR, MoCo-med                       |
| Evaluation      | F1, Dice, IoU, CV                      |
| Post-Processing | Morph Ops + Thresholding               |

---

This pipeline leverages both labeled and unlabeled data, handles stain inconsistency, and balances model complexity with robustness. Fine-tune all stages based on validation scores and challenge-specific feedback.

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: 🎯 **Greedy Sampling vs Weighted Sampling (a.k.a. Probabilistic Sampling)**
text:
Imagine you have a list of options and each option has a score (like how likely the model thinks this token should come next).

Example scores:

|Token|Score|
|---|---|
|"cat"|0.40|
|"dog"|0.30|
|"car"|0.20|
|"banana"|0.10|

---

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: 🟩 **1. Greedy Sampling = Always pick the highest score**
text:
Greedy = "take the best-looking choice _every time_."

So you always pick **"cat"** because it has the highest score (0.40).

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: ✔ Pros
text:
- Deterministic (same input → same output)
    
- Predictable and safe

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: ❌ Cons
text:
- Can be boring and repetitive
    
- Often gets stuck in loops
    
- Lacks creativity

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: 💡 Example
text:
Prompt: _“Once upon a time”_

Greedy model might always continue with something like:

> "Once upon a time **there was a**..."

Every. Single. Time.

---

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: 🟦 **2. Weighted Sampling = Pick randomly, but weighted by scores**
text:
Also called:

- **probabilistic sampling**
    
- **sampling with probabilities**
    
- **multinomial sampling**
    

Here, you **roll a weighted dice**:

- “cat” has 40% chance
    
- “dog” has 30%
    
- “car” has 20%
    
- “banana” has 10%
    

Most of the time you'll still get “cat” or "dog", but sometimes "banana" shows up.

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: ✔ Pros
text:
- Creative
    
- Diverse answers
    
- Avoids repetition loops

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: ❌ Cons
text:
- Less predictable
    
- Can generate nonsense if temperature is high

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: 💡 Example
text:
Same prompt: _“Once upon a time”_

Weighted sampling might generate:

- "Once upon a time **a dragon appeared**."
    
- "Once upon a time **I woke up hungry**."
    
- "Once upon a time **the world ended**."
    

Each run is different.

---

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: 🆚 **In One Line**
text:
**Greedy = always pick the #1 option.**  
**Weighted = pick randomly, but with probabilities matching likelihood.**

---


---

title: greedy vs random sampling
heading: 🔥 Bonus: Why LLMs often don't use greedy
text:
Because greedy gets stuck in:

- repetitive loops (“the the the the”)
    
- boring, predictable completions
    
- less coherent long outputs
    

Weighted sampling gives more **human-like variety and creativity**.

title: Hardware concurrency
heading: ROOT
text: hardware concurrency doesn't have to have dual core to perform genuine concurrency, as it depends on the [[Hardware threads]]

title: Hardware threads
heading: ROOT
text:
hardware threads: is the term that is given to the number of threads/tasks that a hardware(processor) can **genuinely** run at once/concurrently.

So a processor with 2 cores can at least run 2 tasks concurrently, but some processors families can have features like the pipelining which enable it to run 3 or 4 threads concurrently .

Note :  when we say "genuinely" we are not talking about Task switching which is just an illusion of concurrency

which are of main concern to the research community
in the area of network intrusion detection systems
(NIDS). Prior studies such as (Sadotra & Sharma, 2016;

title: IDS presentation
heading: ROOT
text:
[[IDS presentation notes|mynotes]]
Here’s a step-by-step guide for your presentation on **Performance Metrics** and **Datasets and Quality of Datasets** based on the provided paper. Each section includes slide content and presentation notes.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 1: Title Slide**
text:
- **Title:** Performance Metrics and Dataset Quality in Intrusion Detection Systems
- **Subtitle:** Insights from IDS-2019 Survey
- **Your Name & Date**

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 2: Introduction to IDS Evaluation**
text:
- **Title:** Why Evaluate Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS)?
- **Content:**
    - Importance of performance evaluation in IDS:
        - Ensure effective anomaly and attack detection.
        - Balance detection accuracy with real-world applicability.
    - Key aspects of IDS evaluation:
        1. Performance Metrics.
        2. Quality of Datasets.
- **Notes:**
    - Introduce the importance of evaluating IDSs.
    - Highlight how metrics and datasets form the core of IDS assessment.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 3: Performance Metrics Overview**
text:
- **Title:** Metrics for IDS Performance Evaluation
- **Content:**
    - **Confusion Matrix Components:**
        - True Positive (TP): Correctly detected attacks.
        - True Negative (TN): Correctly identified normal traffic.
        - False Positive (FP): Normal traffic flagged as attacks.
        - False Negative (FN): Missed attacks.
    - Metrics Derived:
        - **True Positive Rate (TPR) / Sensitivity:** TPR=TPTP+FN\text{TPR} = \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FN}}TPR=TP+FNTP​
        - **False Positive Rate (FPR):** FPR=FPFP+TN\text{FPR} = \frac{\text{FP}}{\text{FP} + \text{TN}}FPR=FP+TNFP​
        - **Accuracy:** Accuracy=TP+TNTotal Instances\text{Accuracy} = \frac{\text{TP} + \text{TN}}{\text{Total Instances}}Accuracy=Total InstancesTP+TN​
        - **Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC):** TPR vs. FPR curve.
- **Notes:**
    - Explain how these metrics determine IDS reliability and false alarm management.
    - Mention the trade-offs between TPR and FPR in real-world scenarios.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 4: Insights on Performance Metrics**
text:
- **Title:** Evaluating IDS Performance Metrics
- **Content:**
    - **True Positive Rate (TPR):** Measures detection strength; higher TPR means better attack coverage.
    - **False Positive Rate (FPR):** Impacts user trust; low FPR is critical for operational efficiency.
    - **ROC Curve:** Visual representation of the trade-off between TPR and FPR.
    - **Classification Accuracy:** General effectiveness but does not highlight specific weaknesses.
- **Notes:**
    - Dive deeper into the implications of each metric.
    - Emphasize why a balanced approach is critical for deployment.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 5: Datasets Used in IDS**
text:
- **Title:** Intrusion Detection Datasets
- **Content:**
    - Datasets play a pivotal role in IDS evaluation and benchmarking.
    - Popular datasets:
        - **DARPA/KDD Cup 99:** Early benchmark, criticized for outdated attacks and redundant data.
        - **NSL-KDD:** Improved version of KDD 99 with fewer duplicates.
        - **ADFA-LD/ADFA-WD:** Includes modern attack scenarios and system call traces.
        - **CICIDS 2017:** Realistic traffic with diverse attack types.
        - **Bot-IoT:** IoT-focused attacks and traffic patterns.
    - Dataset features:
        - Labeled vs. Unlabeled.
        - Coverage of attack types (zero-day attacks, DoS, R2L, etc.).
        - Realistic traffic generation.
- **Notes:**
    - Explain the evolution of datasets from DARPA to CICIDS.
    - Mention the challenges of dataset quality and relevance.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 6: Dataset Quality Challenges**
text:
- **Title:** Quality Issues in IDS Datasets
- **Content:**
    - **Challenges:**
        - Lack of diversity in attack scenarios.
        - High duplication rates (e.g., KDD Cup 99).
        - Outdated attacks not reflecting modern threats.
        - Synthetic vs. real-world traffic trade-offs.
        - Limited IoT attack data.
    - **Solutions:**
        - Inclusion of zero-day attack data.
        - Elimination of duplicate instances.
        - Use of mixed traffic sources (real + synthetic).
- **Notes:**
    - Emphasize the limitations researchers face due to dataset quality.
    - Discuss the balance between creating comprehensive and manageable datasets.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 7: Case Study - NSL-KDD**
text:
- **Title:** NSL-KDD Dataset Example
- **Content:**
    - Key Features:
        - Derived from KDD Cup 99.
        - 125,973 training records; 22,544 test records.
        - Reduced redundancy.
    - Limitations:
        - Still lacks modern attack patterns.
        - Network topologies and OS behaviors differ from current environments.
- **Notes:**
    - Highlight NSL-KDD's improvements and its limitations in contemporary IDS research.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 8: Recommendations for Better Evaluation**
text:
- **Title:** Improving IDS Metrics and Datasets
- **Content:**
    - **For Metrics:**
        - Include additional metrics like Precision and F1 Score.
        - Evaluate computational overhead for real-time systems.
    - **For Datasets:**
        - Update datasets with modern, realistic traffic and IoT scenarios.
        - Promote open-source sharing of anonymized real-world datasets.
        - Standardize benchmarking protocols.
- **Notes:**
    - Suggest actionable steps for enhancing IDS evaluation.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 9: Summary**
text:
- **Title:** Takeaways
- **Content:**
    - Performance metrics are essential for evaluating IDS capabilities but must balance accuracy and usability.
    - Dataset quality directly impacts IDS reliability.
    - Modernization and diversification of datasets are crucial for realistic evaluations.
- **Notes:**
    - Summarize the discussion.
    - Reinforce the interdependence of metrics and datasets.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Slide 10: Questions**
text:
- **Title:** Thank You!
- **Content:**
    - "Questions?" with a background image relevant to intrusion detection.
- **Notes:**
    - Open the floor for questions and discussion.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Presentation Notes for Delivery**
text:
1. Start with enthusiasm and explain the significance of IDS evaluation.
2. Move through each slide with clarity, providing examples and simplifying complex metrics.
3. Use the slides on datasets to transition to challenges and solutions, keeping the audience engaged.
4. Conclude by reiterating key points and inviting questions.

If you’d like, I can help you create these slides using PowerPoint or Google Slides templates!

title: IDS presentation
heading: You said:
text: Can you explain to me how does the datasets affect the ids evaluation and explain more about the datasets mentioned

title: IDS presentation
heading: ChatGPT said:
text: ChatGPT

title: IDS presentation
heading: How Datasets Affect IDS Evaluation
text: Datasets play a **critical role** in the evaluation of Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) for the following reasons:

title: IDS presentation
heading: 1. **Training and Testing Accuracy**
text:
- IDS algorithms, especially those based on machine learning, require labeled datasets to learn patterns of normal and anomalous behavior.
- If the dataset is not representative of real-world traffic or modern attack scenarios, the IDS may perform well on the dataset but fail in real deployments.

title: IDS presentation
heading: 2. **Generalization**
text: - High-quality datasets ensure the IDS can generalize to unseen attack types and traffic patterns. Low diversity in datasets leads to overfitting, where the IDS learns dataset-specific patterns rather than general behaviors.

title: IDS presentation
heading: 3. **Realism**
text: - Datasets that include realistic traffic with modern attack techniques better simulate operational conditions. Synthetic or outdated datasets may not adequately test IDS performance in real-world scenarios.

title: IDS presentation
heading: 4. **Imbalance**
text: - Many datasets suffer from class imbalance (e.g., more normal traffic than attacks). This imbalance can bias IDS models to favor normal traffic, leading to higher false negative rates for rare but critical attacks.

title: IDS presentation
heading: 5. **Metrics Accuracy**
text:
- Poor-quality datasets (e.g., those with duplicates or mislabeled data) can lead to misleading performance metrics, creating a false sense of IDS effectiveness.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: Overview of Datasets Mentioned in the Paper
text: Here’s a breakdown of the datasets described in the IDS-2019 paper:

title: IDS presentation
heading: **1. DARPA/KDD Cup 99**
text:
- **Description:**
    - Created in 1998-1999 for evaluating IDS.
    - Contains simulated traffic from a US Air Force LAN with attacks interwoven.
- **Features:**
    - 41 attributes representing TCP connections.
    - Includes both normal and attack traffic (DoS, probing, R2L, and U2R attacks).
- **Limitations:**
    - Outdated attack scenarios.
    - High duplication rate (~78% of records are duplicates).
    - Unrealistic network traffic.
- **Impact:**
    - Leads to biased IDS models that fail to generalize to modern threats.

title: IDS presentation
heading: **2. NSL-KDD**
text:
- **Description:**
    - Improved version of KDD Cup 99, developed in 2009.
    - Eliminates duplicate records to reduce bias.
- **Features:**
    - 22 types of attacks.
    - Includes connection-related attributes like protocol type and service.
- **Limitations:**
    - Still lacks modern malware and IoT attack patterns.
    - Does not represent diverse network topologies.
- **Impact:**
    - Provides a cleaner benchmark but remains limited for evaluating modern IDS.

title: IDS presentation
heading: **3. ADFA-LD and ADFA-WD**
text:
- **Description:**
    - Developed by the Australian Defence Force Academy.
    - ADFA-LD focuses on Linux-based systems; ADFA-WD on Windows.
- **Features:**
    - Includes system call traces.
    - Represents modern attacks such as password brute force and remote file inclusion.
- **Limitations:**
    - Limited diversity of traffic and attack types.
- **Impact:**
    - Useful for testing Host-based IDS but not comprehensive for Network-based IDS.

title: IDS presentation
heading: **4. CICIDS2017**
text:
- **Description:**
    - Created in 2017 with modern attack types (e.g., Brute Force, DoS, Botnet).
    - Includes a mix of benign and malicious traffic.
- **Features:**
    - 80 network flow features such as timestamp, source/destination IP, and protocols.
    - Realistic traffic generated in a controlled environment.
- **Limitations:**
    - Requires preprocessing due to high dimensionality.
- **Impact:**
    - One of the most widely used datasets for evaluating modern IDS.

title: IDS presentation
heading: **5. Bot-IoT**
text:
- **Description:**
    - Focused on Internet of Things (IoT) attacks and traffic patterns.
    - Includes attacks like data exfiltration and privilege escalation.
- **Features:**
    - Captures IoT-specific behaviors and vulnerabilities.
- **Limitations:**
    - Limited real-world diversity as IoT deployments vary greatly.
- **Impact:**
    - Critical for IoT-specific IDS but requires augmentation with broader datasets.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Challenges**
text:
- **Lack of Modern Scenarios:** Most older datasets (e.g., KDD) do not include modern threats like ransomware or IoT attacks.
- **Synthetic Data:** Simulated traffic often lacks the unpredictability of real-world networks.
- **Limited Scope:** Some datasets focus only on specific environments (e.g., host-based, Linux systems).

title: IDS presentation
heading: **Recommendations**
text:
- Use **mixed datasets** (real and synthetic) to balance diversity and reproducibility.
- Incorporate **zero-day attacks** and modern malware in datasets.
- Ensure datasets represent **realistic traffic patterns** for IoT and cloud environments.
- Promote open-source **dataset sharing** among research communities to improve standardization.

---

title: IDS presentation
heading: Why Datasets Matter in Real-World Applications
text:
An IDS trained and tested on high-quality datasets is more likely to:

1. Detect real-world attacks, including previously unseen zero-day threats.
2. Minimize false alarms, ensuring that operational environments remain efficient.
3. Adapt to evolving attack methodologies, such as encrypted traffic or obfuscated malware.

Would you like a detailed comparison table summarizing the datasets?

title: initialization and assignment C++
heading: Difference between  initialization and assignment C++ ?
text:
Initialization : giving a variable an initial value at the moment it is created

assignment : giving a variable a value later after the variable is created

assignment  cannot be done in a global context because the compiler will not pass by

```cpp
int y = 20 ; // value initialization note: this is definition

int x ; // default value initialization (0 or garbage) note: this is also definition

x = 20; // copy assignment, will produce error if in global context
```

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Problem formulation
text: The classic egg drop problem asks for the minimum number of drops needed to determine the breaking floor of a building with n floors using at most k eggs, where the breaking floor is the lowest floor from which an egg could be dropped and break. This problem has a closed form solution, but can also be solved with dynamic programming (Exercise!). However, if the building does not have an elevator, one might instead want to minimize the total drop height: the sum of heights from which eggs are dropped. Suppose each of the n floors of the building has a known positive integer height hi, where floor heights strictly increase with i. Given these heights, describe an O(n3k)-time algorithm to return the minimum total drop height required to determine the breaking floor of the building using at most k eggs.

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Classic Problem
text:
![[Classic_egg_drop]]
in the classic problem we try to minimize the number of drops (attempts)

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Classic 1- Egg  algorithm
text:
if we only had one egg, we could follow a very easy plan, by starting from bottom, dropping the egg, and check if it breaks or not .

---

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Lazy-Egg Drop assumptions
text:
- Heights vary from floor to floor
- Heights are sorted
- All eggs have the same mechanical property
- We try to minimize the total height from which the egg breaks in the **worst** case

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Naive recursive approach
text: This algorithm solves the Lazy Egg Drop Problem by exploring every possible way to drop eggs from floors, calculating the worst-case total drop height for each strategy, and picking the **minimum** worst-case height.

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Notations
text:
- i : starting floor
- j : ending floor
- f : current floor number
- e : number of eggs remaining

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Recurrence relation
text: MinHeight(k,i,j) = = min{f_height + max{MinHeight(i, f − 1, e − 1), MinHeight(f + 1, j, e)}}

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Base case :
text:
- Eggs are all consumed, but floors still left to check (= ∞)
- No more floors to check and there are still eggs left (=0)(no drops needed)(total drop height = 0)


Code

``` Python

function find_min_total_height(i, j, e, H):
    # Base Case 1: No floors left to check
    if i > j:
        return 0

    # Base Case 2: No eggs left but floors remain
    if e == 0:
        return ∞

    # Base Case 3: Only 1 egg left (must check sequentially)
    if e == 1:
        total = 0
        for floor in range(i, j + 1):
            total += H[floor]
        return total

    # Recursive Case: Try dropping from each floor f in [i, j]
    min_height = ∞

    for f in range(i, j + 1):
        # Scenario 1: Egg breaks → check floors below f
        cost_if_breaks = find_min_total_height(i, f - 1, e - 1, H)

        # Scenario 2: Egg survives → check floors above f
        cost_if_survives = find_min_total_height(f + 1, j, e, H)

        # Total cost for dropping at floor f
        current_cost = H[f] + max(cost_if_breaks, cost_if_survives)

        # Track the minimum worst-case cost
        if current_cost < min_height:
            min_height = current_cost

    return min_height

```

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Time complexity
text:
- At each step, we make up to n recursive calls (for each floor choice).
- The recursion tree has a branching factor of n and depth up to k

 `find_min_total_height(5, 10, 2, H)` might be called after an initial drop at floor 4 (if it didn't break) and also after an initial drop at floor 15 (if it broke, and a subsequent drop at floor 11 didn't break, etc.)

therefore : **exponential time**

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Space Complexity
text:
maximum depth of the recursion stack O(K+N)

---

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: DP Approach
text:
We add memoization to the solution to avoid calculating the same subproblem twice
by adding a memoization table  (`dp[i][j][e]`)

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: **Changes to Code:**

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Time Complexity
text:
for a problem X(1,n,k)
subproblems  N^2 x k  = O(n^2 k)
work per subproblem = O(n)
Total = O(n^3k)

title: Lazy Egg-Drop Problem
heading: Space Complexity
text:
- **O(n^2 k)** (memoization table)
- Stores results for all `(i, j, e)` combinations in a 3D table.
- Example: For n=100 and k=2, the table has 100×100×2=20,000 entries.
---

Next up : Greedy

title: loosely typed programming language
heading: ROOT
text:
a loosely typed programming language is one that allow mixing types in operations implicitly(automatically converts them when needed)

Example (JavaScript) which is loosely typed:
```js
console.log("5" + 1);  // "51"   (string concatenation)
console.log("5" - 1);  // 4      (string coerced to number)
console.log(true + 1); // 2      (true → 1)

```

Example(C++) which is strongly typed : 
```cpp
std::string s = "5";
int n = 1;
std::cout << s + n;  // ❌ error, must cast explicitly
```

title: Make
heading: ROOT
text:
Make Rules :

```Make

target : prerequisites
	Recipe

```

If target already exist, make checks if the prerequisites are more recent than target, if they are, make will recompile Target using the recipe, otherwise it's already up to date and make will output a message saying that "target" is already up to date 

the exception to this is if the target is listed as a phony target,
in this case make will always execute this target . see [Phony Targets]




If there are more than one rule, and you type make without specifying the target
1 - if you have a .DEFAULT_GOAL manually set to a target, make will execute this target
2- if you don't manually set .DEFAULT_GOAL, it will be automatically set to the first target in the makefile 


```make

.DEFAULT_GOAL := qnx_application

test:

    @echo "default goals is automatically set"
qnx_application:

    @echo "default goals is manually set"
```
executing make without arguments will output >> "default goals is manually set"

```

test:

    @echo "default goals is automatically set"

qnx_application:

    @echo "default goals is manually set"
```
executing make without arguments will output >> "default goals is automatically set"



important variables

$<  the first prerequisite
$?   only the prerequisites that are newer than the target

title: Memory Allocation C++
heading: Memory Allocation types
text:
1.  Static memory allocation : for static and global variables ([[.bss]] and [[.data]])
2.  Automatic memory allocation : for local variables and function parameters ([[stack]])
3. [[Dynamic memory allocation C++ | Dynamic memory allocation ]] : for dynamically allocated variables using [[new keyword]] ([[heap]])



---
{{References}}

title: Memory Leak
heading: ROOT
text:
Memory Leak is when you create objects using [[Dynamic memory allocation C++  | Dynamic Memory Allocation]] and don't delete it before the address of the object is lost. 

---
Address is lost due to :
1. Pointer gets out of scope
2. Pointer is reassigned to point to another variable
3. Double allocation

example 1 Pointer gets out of scope :
```cpp
void doSomething(void)
{
	int* int_ptr {new (std::nothrow) int {10}};
}
int main ()
{
	doSomething(); // memory leak happens after we exit the function

	// rest of the application
}
```

example 2 Pointer reassigned :
```cpp
int var = 20;
int* int_ptr {new (std::nothrow) int {10}};
int_ptr = &var ; // memory leak happens here because the memory allocated to int_ptr was not deleted before reassigning
```

example 3 Double allocation :

```cpp
int * int_ptr {new (std::nothrow) int {10}};
int_ptr = new int {50}; // memory leak happens here because memory allocated to int_ptr was not freed before second allocation

```


---


When the dynamically allocated memory is not deleted, before the application loses the address, so it cannot delete it && the operating system cannot use it .

so memory leak result in a free memory that cannot be used by the operating system

Severe memory leak problems cause the entire machine to run slowly or even crash . After the application that causes the memory leak terminates, the operating system reclaims the leaked memory .

text: I will leave one little story here, as it relates to this video. If you are someone that feels like you are not smart enough to succeed, then this story is for you. I was one of the worst students back in my middle school. I remember being the only one not able to understand stuff in math class that basically everyone understood. The teacher even pulled me aside to talk to me. Failing lots of tests, from multiple subjects... even though I studied a decent amount of time... Eventually, I realized I needed to increase my intelligence. This is different from getting good grades. This is about increasing your comprehension, creativity and brainpower. I thought that math problems, not those from school, were the path. So I started at them. I started easy, getting the easiest math olympiad problems I could find. Some are really easy, but even those took me lots of time reading the solutions to understand. But eventually, these started to actually become understandable to me... so I started ramping up the difficulty... I spent hours and hours everyday solving these problems, and eventually reached IMO level (International Mathematical Olympiad - though I did not make it to the actual team, I was selected as one of the potential participants, but basically everyone on the team selection tests were at least bronze level). I also became one of the top students from my country, and also a National Math and Informatics Olympic medalist. I studied for free at the top school, by getting the highest markings on the scholarship competition. It took a few years of daily study, but patience is a huge monster skill to have. Your brain just takes time to build itself. You wouldn't think of rushing a broken arm, right? Afterwards I got scouted by a top investment bank... at their best tradi

title: Motivational 1
heading: ROOT
text: is a huge monster skill to have. Your brain just takes time to build itself. You wouldn't think of rushing a broken arm, right? Afterwards I got scouted by a top investment bank... at their best trading desk. Got the top score on their logic test by a mile. But this is getting out of topic. What I want to teach with this story of mine is that even if you are not too smart now, you can become a top tier intellectual being by sheer effort, unless maybe if you have a special condition. But in general, if you do this, solve lots of math problems, ramping up difficulty until you reach international level, you WILL become a supreme genius. Every one of the math champions that I met worked very hard to reach that level. All of them entered top schools, top jobs, etc. It really is a matter of putting in the hours... I did maybe 2 or 3 hours of math solving everyday, some days on vacation from school I did 4, 6 or 10 hours... It is a lot of work, but I guess most of the great rewards come from hard, grueling work. And mind you, I was in middle/high school. Some practical tips: get easy problems first, and try to learn one per day until you get the habit. Note that I used "learn" instead of "solve". Focus on raising your understanding, not on immediately being a top solver. Try all your obvious ideas first, and if that does not work, than start a timer for 15 minutes. Think for 15 minutes, searching for new ideas. Then read part of the solution, and try to finish the rest. Keep doing it until you get the entire solution. Also, try to understand how you could have reached that solution. How did the guy who solved it think about such an esoteric idea? You need to ponder these kinds of things, to increase your intuition. Sketch a lot. You need pen and paper. Read how the top math ch

title: Motivational 1
heading: ROOT
text: n. How did the guy who solved it think about such an esoteric idea? You need to ponder these kinds of things, to increase your intuition. Sketch a lot. You need pen and paper. Read how the top math champions came to be and read their tips. Hope this helps someone, and also that I did not come off as arrogant. It is hard to talk about these experiences without causing the impression of "showing off" or something like that. But I also believe it may help someone. I for sure would have liked to read these words back in the day. Would have sped up my progress. If you feel you do not have a future, please believe that you can have a great life. I know it seems hopeless sometimes, but our comprehension gets limited when attacked by extreme stress and sadness. Work hard, have patience, it takes a few years, but if you put in the effort on the right things, you will most probably achieve "success". Though by then your definition of success will probably be different. Edited for typos.

title: PV architecture
heading: AI4PV DVP Generator: Software Architecture and User Experience
text: This document outlines the software architecture and user experience for the AI for Product Validation (AI4PV) - DVP Generator application.

title: PV architecture
heading: A. User Story
text:
As a Product Validation Engineer, I am constantly under pressure to create comprehensive and accurate Design Verification Plans (DVPs) for new automotive components. This process is time-consuming and prone to human error, as it requires me to manually sift through dozens of dense specification documents (like DVRs, CCMs, and customer requirements) just to identify the necessary test cases. Any missed requirement can lead to costly compliance issues and project delays.

  

I need a tool that can automate this entire workflow. I want to be able to log in securely with my company Google account and start a new DVP project by defining its scope—like the division (e.g., LIGHT, BRAIN) and the customer. Then, I want to upload all my relevant specification documents in one go, regardless of their format (PDF, Excel, etc.).

  

Once the documents are uploaded, I need the system to intelligently analyze them and present me with a clear, filterable list of all potential test cases. This allows me to quickly review and select the exact tests required for the current plan. After making my selection, I want the tool to generate a complete DVP document, pre-formatted in our standard Markdown template. This generated plan should not just be a list of tests, but a full-fledged document with sections for Test Objectives, Procedures, and Acceptance Criteria.

  

The initial draft is rarely perfect, so I need an intuitive way to make corrections. Instead of manually editing the document, I want to use a chat-like interface to give commands in plain English, such as, "Change the test voltage to 12V," and see the document update in real-time. This interactive process would be incredibly efficient.

  

Finally, once I am satisfied with the DVP, I need to export it as a professional, form

title: PV architecture
heading: A. User Story
text:
e to 12V," and see the document update in real-time. This interactive process would be incredibly efficient.

  

Finally, once I am satisfied with the DVP, I need to export it as a professional, formatted `.docx` file, ready for formal review and distribution. This entire process would transform a week's worth of tedious work into a few hours of focused validation, ensuring accuracy and freeing me up to focus on more critical engineering tasks.

title: PV architecture
heading: 1. System Context Diagram (Level 1)
text:
```mermaid

C4Context

  title System Context Diagram for AI4PV DVP Generator

  

  Person(ValidationEngineer, "Product Validation Engineer", "Generates DVPs using the system.")

  

  System_Ext(GoogleIdentity, "Google Identity", "Provides Google-based authentication (OAuth).")

  System_Ext(LLM_API, "LLM Gateway", "Provides AI models for test case extraction and DVP generation.")

  System_Ext(GCS, "Google Cloud Storage", "Stores uploaded specification documents.")

  System_Ext(Firestore, "Firestore", "Stores DVP project metadata and user permissions.")

  System_Ext(UserManagement, "User Management Service", "Manages user authorization and access control.")

  

  System(AI4PV_System, "AI4PV DVP Generator", "Allows engineers to automatically generate DVPs from specification documents.")

  

  Rel(ValidationEngineer, AI4PV_System, "Uses")

  Rel(AI4PV_System, GoogleIdentity, "Authenticates users via")

  Rel(AI4PV_System, LLM_API, "Makes API calls to")

  Rel(AI4PV_System, GCS, "Stores and retrieves files from")

  Rel(AI4PV_System, Firestore, "Stores and retrieves metadata from")

  Rel(AI4PV_System, UserManagement, "Checks permissions with")

```

title: PV architecture
heading: 2. Container Diagram (Level 2)
text:
```mermaid

C4Container

  title Container Diagram for AI4PV DVP Generator

  

  Person(ValidationEngineer, "Product Validation Engineer", "Generates DVPs.")

  

  System_Ext(GoogleIdentity, "Google Identity", "Provides Google-based authentication.")

  System_Ext(LLM_API, "Large Language Model API", "Generates test cases and DVPs.")

  System_Ext(UserManagement, "User Management Service", "Manages user authorization.")

  

  System_Boundary(AI4PV_System, "AI4PV DVP Generator") {

    Container(Frontend, "Frontend Web App", "React, TypeScript, Vite", "The user's primary interface for creating DVPs.")

    Container(Backend, "Backend API", "Python, FastAPI", "Provides a REST API for file handling, DVP generation, and persistence.")

  

    ContainerDb(GCS, "File Storage", "Google Cloud Storage Bucket", "Stores uploaded specification documents.")

    ContainerDb(Firestore, "Metadata Store", "Firestore Database", "Stores DVP project metadata, test lists, and permissions.")

  

    Rel(Frontend, Backend, "Makes API calls to", "HTTPS/JSON")

    Rel(Backend, GCS, "Reads/Writes files to/from", "GCS API")

    Rel(Backend, Firestore, "Reads/Writes data to/from", "Firestore API")

  }

  

  Rel(ValidationEngineer, Frontend, "Uses", "HTTPS")

  Rel(Frontend, GoogleIdentity, "Authenticates user with", "OAuth 2.0")

  Rel(Backend, LLM_API, "Sends prompts to", "HTTPS/JSON")

  Rel(Backend, UserManagement, "Validates user permissions with", "HTTPS/JSON")

```

title: PV architecture
heading: 3. Component Diagram (Level 3 - Backend)

```mermaid

C4Component

  title Component Diagram for Backend API

  

  Container(Frontend, "Frontend Web App", "React", "The user's primary interface.")
```
