  ContainerDb(GCS, "File Storage", "GCS Bucket", "Stores specification documents.")

  System_Boundary(Backend, "Backend API (FastAPI)") {

    Component(UploadRouter, "Upload Router", "FastAPI Router", "Handles all file upload requests.")

    Component(TestTableRouter, "Test Table Router", "FastAPI Router", "Manages test case extraction and listing.")

    Rel(UploadRouter, GCSController, "Uses")

    Rel(TestTableRouter,

title: PV architecture
heading: 1. List Test Cases
text:
```mermaid

sequenceDiagram

    actor User

    participant Frontend

    participant Backend

    participant LLM_API

    participant GCS

  

    User->>Frontend: 1. Uploads spec files (PDF, Excel)

    Frontend->>Backend: 2. POST /upload (file data)

    Backend->>GCS: 3. Store file and get identifier

    GCS-->>Backend: 4. Returns file identifier

    Backend-->>Frontend: 5. Returns success status

    User->>Frontend: 6. Clicks "List Tests"

    Frontend->>Backend: 7. POST /list-tests (with file identifiers)

    Backend->>GCS: 8. Retrieve file content for analysis

    GCS-->>Backend: 9. Returns file content

    Backend->>LLM_API: 10. "Extract test cases from these documents: [content]"

    LLM_API-->>Backend: 11. Returns structured list of test cases (CSV/JSON)

    Backend->>Frontend: 12. Forwards test case list

    Frontend->>User: 13. Displays test cases in a filterable data grid

```

title: PV architecture
heading: 2. Generate and Correct DVP
text:
```mermaid

sequenceDiagram

    actor User

    participant Frontend

    participant Backend

    participant LLM_API

    participant Firestore

  

    User->>Frontend: 1. Selects test cases from grid

    User->>Frontend: 2. Clicks "Generate"

    Frontend->>Backend: 3. POST /generate (with selected test cases)

    Backend->>LLM_API: 4. "Generate a DVP in Markdown with these tests: [tests]"

    LLM_API-->>Backend: 5. Returns full DVP in Markdown format

    Backend->>Firestore: 6. Store generated DVP and metadata

    Firestore-->>Backend: 7. Confirm storage

    Backend-->>Frontend: 8. Returns DVP Markdown

    Frontend->>User: 9. Renders Markdown in an interactive canvas

  

    %% Correction Loop %%

    User->>Frontend: 10. Clicks on a section and types a correction query

    Frontend->>Backend: 11. POST /correct (section_id, "Update temp to -40 to 125C")

    Backend->>LLM_API: 12. "Update this section: [original_text] with this instruction: [query]"

    LLM_API-->>Backend: 13. Returns updated Markdown for the section

    Backend->>Firestore: 14. Update DVP with the corrected section

    Firestore-->>Backend: 15. Confirm update

    Backend-->>Frontend: 16. Returns updated Markdown section

    Frontend->>User: 17. Re-renders the specific section in the canvas

```

title: SIGBUS

text:
a signal generated to report that the program tried to dereference an uninitialized pointer

Difference between SIGBUS and [[Segmentation fault C++| SIGSEGV ]] 
is that SIGSEGV is trying an invalid access to a valid memory
while SIGUG is an invalid access to an invalid memory


SIGBUS often result from dereferencing a misaligned pointer
such as referring to a four-word integer at an address not divisible by four, for example accessing a 4-byte integer at an address like 0x1003

title: statefulness comaprison table
heading: ROOT
text:
| Concept                      | Type                   | Statefulness                                                             | How it works                                                                                                         | Notes                                                                         |
| ---------------------------- | ---------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **OAuth (protocol)**         | Authorization protocol | **Depends**                                                              | Defines flow to request/issue tokens from an authorization server                                                    | Protocol itself is neutral; implementation may track issued tokens (stateful) |
| **[[oauth]] Access Token**   | Token                  | **Stateless** (if JWT) / **Stateful** (if opaque)                        | JWT tokens carry all info and can be verified without server storage; opaque tokens require server to track them     | Short-lived; often paired with refresh tokens                                 |
| **[[JWT]] (JSON Web Token)** | Token format           | **Stateless**                                                            | Token contains claims + signature; server verifies signature without storing session                                 | Can be used in OAuth or your own app’s authentication                         |
| **[[Cookies]] (session)**    | Storage/transport      | **Stateful** (for traditional sessions) / **Stateless** (if storing JWT) | Browser

text:
There are 2 types of concurrency:

1- [[Hardware concurrency]]
2- [[Task Switching]]


Note that hardware concurrency doesn't have to have dual core to perform genuine concurrency, as it depends on the Hardware threads


Most of the times, real modern systems has both task switching and hardware concurrency

title: Untitled 10
heading: ROOT
text:
````
```mermaid
erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK "User ID"
        string email "Email (Unique)"
        string full_name "Full Name"
        string hashed_password "Hashed Password"
        string role "User Role"
        datetime created_at "Creation Timestamp"
    }

    PRODUCT {
        int id PK "Product ID"
        string title "Product Title"
        string description "Description"
        string category "Category"
        string image_url "Image URL"
        numeric price "Price"
        string currency "Currency"
    }

    USER_SESSION {
        string id PK "Session ID (UUID)"
        int user_id FK "User ID"
        datetime created_at "Creation Timestamp"
        datetime expires_at "Expiration Timestamp"
        boolean is_active "Is Active?"
        string ip_address "IP Address"
        string user_agent "User Agent"
    }

    LIKED_PRODUCT {
        int user_id PK, FK "User ID"
        int product_id PK, FK "Product ID"
        datetime liked_at "Like Timestamp"
    }

    USER ||--o{ USER_SESSION : "has"
    USER }o--|| LIKED_PRODUCT : "likes"
    PRODUCT }o--|| LIKED_PRODUCT : "is liked by"

````

title: Untitled 10
heading: How to Read This Diagram
text:
- **Boxes**: Each box represents a database table (`USER`, `PRODUCT`, etc.).
    
- **Columns**: Inside each box are the columns, their data types, and a short description. `PK` marks a Primary Key, and `FK` marks a Foreign Key.
    
- **Lines**: The lines show the relationships between the tables.
    
    - `USER ||--o{ USER_SESSION`: This is a **one-to-many** relationship. One `USER` can have many `USER_SESSION` records.
        
    - `USER }o--|| LIKED_PRODUCT`: This shows that the `USER` table is connected to the `LIKED_PRODUCT` join table.
        
    - `PRODUCT }o--|| LIKED_PRODUCT`: This shows that the `PRODUCT` table is also connected to the `LIKED_PRODUCT` join table. Together, these two lines represent our **many-to-many** relationship.
        

You can also add this diagram to your `README.md` file later under the "Architecture Diagram" section.

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 7 Quiz
text:
**Instructions:** For each question, select all the correct answers. There may be one or more correct answers.

---

**Q1) What is meant by "saturation" in the context of activation functions like sigmoid and tanh?** (a) The function's output becomes very large for large inputs. (b) The function's derivative (gradient) approaches zero for very large positive or negative inputs. (c) The function can only be used in the final layer of a network. (d) The function's output is always equal to the input.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Saturation refers to the phenomenon where the output of the activation function flattens out for inputs of large magnitude (either positive or negative), causing the gradient to become very small.

---

**Q2) What is the primary issue caused by vanishing gradients in deep neural networks?** (a) The network becomes too computationally expensive to train. (b) The parameters in the earlier layers of the network update very slowly or not at all, hindering learning. (c) The model overfits to the training data too quickly. (d) The loss function increases instead of decreasing.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** If the gradient becomes close to zero, there will be almost no change in the parameter values during backpropagation, especially in earlier layers, which means the network stops learning effectively.

---

**Q3) How does the ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit) activation function, defined as ReLU(x)=max(0,x), address the vanishing gradient problem for positive inputs?** (a) It has a derivative that saturates for positive inputs. (b) Its derivative is 1 for all positive inputs, allowing gradients to pass through unchanged. (c) It normalizes the inputs. (d) It randomly sets some positive inputs to zero.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The d

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 7 Quiz
text:
is 1 for all positive inputs, allowing gradients to pass through unchanged. (c) It normalizes the inputs. (d) It randomly sets some positive inputs to zero.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The derivative of ReLU is 1 if x>0 and zero otherwise. This constant derivative of 1 for positive inputs helps prevent the gradient from shrinking as it propagates backward.

---

**Q4) What is a potential issue with the standard ReLU activation function for negative inputs, and how does LeakyReLU attempt to solve it?** (a) ReLU outputs large negative values; LeakyReLU caps them. (b) ReLU outputs zero for negative inputs (zero gradient); LeakyReLU outputs α⋅x (a small non-zero gradient) for negative inputs. (c) ReLU is not differentiable; LeakyReLU is. (d) ReLU is computationally intensive for negative inputs; LeakyReLU is faster.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** For negative inputs, ReLU outputs zero, and its derivative is also zero, which can cause "dead neurons" that stop learning. LeakyReLU addresses this by returning α⋅x for negative inputs, where α is a small constant, allowing a small gradient to flow.

---

**Q5) Normalization layers (like Batch Normalization) are typically applied to the inputs of a hidden layer. What is the general effect of this normalization?** (a) It increases the non-linearity of the model. (b) It re-centers the input data to have a mean of (or close to) 0 and re-scales it to have a standard deviation of (or close to) 1. (c) It reduces the number of parameters in the layer. (d) It replaces the need for an activation function.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Normalization typically involves mean subtraction and division by the standard deviation, transforming the data to have a mean near zero and a standard deviation near one.

---

**Q6) I

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 7 Quiz
text:
Explanation:** Normalization typically involves mean subtraction and division by the standard deviation, transforming the data to have a mean near zero and a standard deviation near one.

---

**Q6) In Batch Normalization, the normalization is performed over which dimensions?** (a) Across all features for a single training example. (b) Across the batch of data, for each feature/channel independently. (c) Across all layers of the network. (d) Only over the spatial dimensions (width and height).

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Batch Normalization normalizes its inputs over each batch of data. For convolutional layers, this normalization is typically applied per channel across the batch and spatial dimensions.

---

**Q7) While normalization layers often improve training, in which scenario might Batch Normalization be less effective or problematic?** (a) When using very deep networks. (b) When using very small batch sizes. (c) When using ReLU activation functions. (d) When the dataset is very large.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** When batch sizes are small, the batch statistics (mean and variance) can be noisy and less representative of the overall dataset, which can make Batch Normalization less effective or even detrimental.

---

**Q8) What is the core idea behind "skip connections" or "residual connections" in network architectures like ResNet?** (a) To skip the computation of certain layers to speed up training. (b) To allow the output of an earlier layer to be added to the output of a deeper layer, creating a "shortcut" for information and gradient flow. (c) To introduce more non-linearity into the network. (d) To reduce the number of channels in feature maps.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Skip connections create a direct path for the input to be ad

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 7 Quiz
text:
o introduce more non-linearity into the network. (d) To reduce the number of channels in feature maps.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Skip connections create a direct path for the input to be added to the output of a block of layers. The output of such a residual layer is f(x)=x+F(x), where x is the input and F(x) is the output of the sub-network. This helps with gradient flow in deep networks.

---

**Q9) How do "dense skip connections" (as seen in DenseNet-like architectures) differ from typical residual connections?** (a) They only connect the first layer to the last layer. (b) Each layer receives the feature maps of all preceding layers as input, and its own feature maps are passed to all subsequent layers (often through concatenation). (c) They only use 1×1 convolutions. (d) They eliminate the need for batch normalization.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Dense skip connections involve connecting each layer to every other layer in a feed-forward fashion. The input to a layer is often the concatenation of the outputs of all previous layers. (See diagram on Lecture 7, page 14).

---

**Q10) What is a significant advantage of using 1×1 convolutions?** (a) They can capture large-scale spatial relationships across the image. (b) They are computationally cheap and can be used to change the number of channels (depth) in a feature map or introduce channel-wise non-linearity. (c) They always increase the spatial dimensions of the output. (d) They eliminate the need for pooling layers.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** 1×1 convolutions are computationally inexpensive operations that can change the number of channels in a layer or apply non-linearity across channels without affecting the spatial resolution.

---

**Q11) A "residual bottleneck" block, as described

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 7 Quiz
text:
e operations that can change the number of channels in a layer or apply non-linearity across channels without affecting the spatial resolution.

---

**Q11) A "residual bottleneck" block, as described in the lecture, often uses 1×1 convolutions for what purpose(s) in its "long path"?** (a) To increase the spatial resolution of the feature maps. (b) The first 1×1 convolution typically reduces the number of channels (bottlenecking), and a later 1×1 convolution restores the number of channels. (c) To perform max pooling. (d) To exclusively add noise for regularization.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** In a residual bottleneck, the long path often includes an initial 1×1 convolution to shrink the number of channels, followed by a more computationally intensive layer (e.g., 3×3 convolution), and then another 1×1 convolution to expand the channels back.

---

**Q12) What is the "forget gate" in an LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) unit primarily responsible for?** (a) Deciding what new information to store in the cell state. (b) Deciding what information to discard from the cell state (Ct−1​). (c) Deciding what part of the cell state to output. (d) Adding non-linearity to the input.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The forget gate uses a sigmoid function to decide which parts of the old cell state Ct−1​ should be forgotten or kept.

---

**Q13) What is the role of the "input gate" in an LSTM unit?** (a) To determine which values from the cell state to output. (b) To control which new information from the current input (xt​) and previous hidden state (ht−1​) should be added to the cell state (Ct​). (c) To erase the entire previous hidden state. (d) To calculate the final output of the LSTM unit.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The input gate, through a sigmoid layer,

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 7 Quiz
text:
the cell state (Ct​). (c) To erase the entire previous hidden state. (d) To calculate the final output of the LSTM unit.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The input gate, through a sigmoid layer, decides which values will be updated. Then, a tanh layer creates a vector of new candidate values that could be added to the state. These two are combined to update the cell state.

---

**Q14) In an LSTM, what are "gating mechanisms" typically implemented with?** (a) Max pooling layers. (b) Sigmoid (σ(⋅)) and tanh activation functions, often combined with linear layers. (c) ReLU activation functions exclusively. (d) 1×1 convolutions only.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Gating mechanisms in LSTMs use sigmoid functions (to produce values between 0 and 1 that act as gates) and often tanh functions (to scale values to be between -1 and 1 before being gated or added to the cell state), typically applied to affine transformations of the inputs.

---

**Q15) Compared to a basic RNN, what is a primary advantage of using LSTMs for processing sequences?** (a) LSTMs have significantly fewer parameters. (b) LSTMs are better at learning and remembering long-range dependencies in sequences due to their gating mechanisms that control information flow. (c) LSTMs can only process fixed-length sequences. (d) LSTMs do not use activation functions.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** LSTMs, with their forget, input, and output gates, are designed to better handle long-term dependencies in sequences by controlling what information is stored in, written to, or read from the cell state, helping to mitigate vanishing/exploding gradient problems over long sequences.

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 8 Quiz
text:
**Instructions:** For each question, select all the correct answers. There may be one or more correct answers.

---

**Q1) What is the core idea behind self-supervised learning?** (a) It requires extensive manually labeled data for training. (b) The learning process uses a regression or classification loss function to predict something about the input data itself. (c) It is primarily used for reinforcement learning tasks. (d) The model learns from data that has labels provided by human annotators.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The idea behind self-supervision is that a regression or classification loss function is used for learning, and the model predicts something about the input data itself. This means labels are derived from the data, not external annotations.

---

**Q2) Which of the following are examples of self-supervision problems mentioned in the lecture?** (a) Image inpainting (filling in missing pieces). (b) Image sorting (putting pieces back in the correct order). (a) Autoencoding (predicting the input as the output). (d) Object detection using pre-labeled bounding boxes.

**Answer(s): (a), (b), (c)** **Explanation:** The lecture lists inpainting, image sorting, and autoencoding as strategies for self-supervision where the task is defined using the input data itself.

---

**Q3) What are the two main components of a typical autoencoder architecture?** (a) A classifier and a regressor. (b) An encoder and a decoder. (c) A generator and a discriminator. (d) A feature extractor and a pooling layer.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** An autoencoder architecture consists of an encoder that maps the input data x to a latent representation z, and a decoder that maps z back to an output that should resemble x.

---

**Q4) What is the primary goal of the deco

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 8 Quiz
text:
ure consists of an encoder that maps the input data x to a latent representation z, and a decoder that maps z back to an output that should resemble x.

---

**Q4) What is the primary goal of the decoder in an autoencoder?** (a) To classify the latent representation. (b) To make its output look as close as possible to the original input data. (c) To further compress the latent representation. (d) To add noise to the latent representation.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The decoder's objective is to reconstruct the original input from the latent representation, meaning its output fout(fin(x)) should be approximately equal to x.

---

**Q5) In the context of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) being framed as a bottleneck autoencoder, what does the "bottleneck" refer to?** (a) The input data having too many features. (b) The encoder mapping the data from a D-dimensional space to a lower D′-dimensional space. (c) The decoder failing to reconstruct the data perfectly. (d) The computational cost of the training process.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** PCA can be viewed as an autoencoder where the encoder reduces the dimensionality of the data from D to D′, creating a bottleneck, and the decoder attempts to reconstruct the original D-dimensional data from this lower-dimensional representation.

---

**Q6) When implementing a linear autoencoder where the decoder uses the transpose of the encoder's weights (tied weights), what is a key characteristic?** (a) The encoder and decoder learn completely independent sets of weights. (b) The weights used in the decoder are directly related to (the transpose of) the weights learned by the encoder. (c) Non-linear activation functions must be used in both encoder and decoder. (d) This approach is only suitable for image data.

*

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 8 Quiz
text:
ly related to (the transpose of) the weights learned by the encoder. (c) Non-linear activation functions must be used in both encoder and decoder. (d) This approach is only suitable for image data.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** In a simple linear autoencoder with tied weights, if the encoder uses a weight matrix W, the decoder would use WT. The `TransposeLinear` class described aims to implement this by sharing weights.

---

**Q7) What is one potential use of an autoencoder's learned latent representation z?** (a) Directly as a method for data augmentation. (b) As input to another classifier or for tasks like clustering and information retrieval. (c) To always increase the dimensionality of the input data. (d) To replace the loss function during training.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The learned latent representation z can be useful for visualization, clustering, information retrieval (e.g., k-nearest neighbor searching), or as input features for other machine learning models.

---

**Q8) What is a "denoising autoencoder"?** (a) An autoencoder that is trained only on perfectly clean, noise-free data. (b) An autoencoder that takes a corrupted or noisy version of the input and is trained to reconstruct the original, clean version. (c) An autoencoder that specifically learns to add optimal noise to data for augmentation. (d) An autoencoder that has no decoder part.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** A denoising autoencoder is trained by adding noise to the encoder's input while still expecting the decoder to produce a clean image, forcing the network to learn how to remove the noise.

---

**Q9) Why might one intentionally add noise to the input of an autoencoder during training (as in a denoising autoencoder)?** (a) To make the training process faster. (

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 8 Quiz
text:
how to remove the noise.

---

**Q9) Why might one intentionally add noise to the input of an autoencoder during training (as in a denoising autoencoder)?** (a) To make the training process faster. (b) To force the model to learn more robust features and to be less sensitive to minor variations in the input data. (c) To ensure the latent representation is always of a higher dimension than the input. (d) To eliminate the need for a bottleneck.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** By training the autoencoder to reconstruct a clean image from a noisy input, the network must learn to identify and remove the noise, leading to more robust feature learning.

---

**Q10) If a PyTorch module contains `if self.training: ... else: ...`, what is the purpose of this conditional statement?** (a) To select different loss functions based on whether the model is training or evaluating. (b) To allow the module to behave differently during the training phase (e.g., apply dropout, add noise) compared to the evaluation/inference phase. (c) To load different datasets for training and evaluation. (d) To change the optimizer based on the current epoch.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The `self.training` attribute in a PyTorch `nn.Module` is a boolean that is `True` when the model is in training mode (set by `model.train()`) and `False` when in evaluation mode (set by `model.eval()`). This allows layers like dropout or custom noise layers to behave differently during these phases.

---

**Q11) When designing an autoencoder, what is a common architectural pattern for the encoder and decoder regarding the number of neurons/features in their layers?** (a) The encoder layers progressively increase in size, and decoder layers decrease. (b) The encoder layers progressively decrease in size to t

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 8 Quiz
text:
garding the number of neurons/features in their layers?** (a) The encoder layers progressively increase in size, and decoder layers decrease. (b) The encoder layers progressively decrease in size to the bottleneck, and decoder layers progressively increase in size from the bottleneck. (c) Both encoder and decoder maintain a constant number of neurons/features. (d) The decoder is always much smaller than the encoder.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** A common pattern for autoencoders is for the encoder to have layers that gradually reduce dimensionality (e.g., D -> D/2 -> D/3 -> D/4 -> n), and the decoder to symmetrically increase dimensionality (e.g., n -> D/4 -> D/3 -> D/2 -> D).

---

**Q12) How can trained autoencoders be used for outlier or anomaly detection?** (a) Outliers will typically have a very low reconstruction error. (b) Data points that have a significantly higher reconstruction error compared to normal training data are likely to be outliers or anomalies. (c) The encoder directly outputs an anomaly score. (d) Autoencoders cannot be used for anomaly detection.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Autoencoders are trained to reconstruct "normal" data well. If new data comes in and the autoencoder produces a high reconstruction error, it suggests the data is unusual or different from what the model was trained on, and thus potentially an outlier.

---

**Q13) What is a key characteristic of "self-supervision" that distinguishes it from traditional supervised learning?** (a) It requires more human effort for labeling. (b) It does not require manually created labels; the supervisory signal is derived from the data itself. (c) It is only applicable to generative models. (d) It always results in lower model accuracy.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Self-

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 8 Quiz
text:
abels; the supervisory signal is derived from the data itself. (c) It is only applicable to generative models. (d) It always results in lower model accuracy.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Self-supervision can be applied to any data and does not require a human to manually label the data because the prediction target is a part of, or derived from, the input itself.

---

**Q14) What is the loss function typically trying to minimize when training a basic autoencoder?** (a) The difference between the latent representation and the input. (b) The difference between the reconstructed output and the original input (e.g., using Mean Squared Error). (c) The number of parameters in the encoder. (d) The dimensionality of the bottleneck layer.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** The training objective for an autoencoder is to minimize the reconstruction error, which is the difference between the decoder's output and the original input x. The loss function quantifies this difference (e.g., l(fout(fin(x)),x)).

---

**Q15) Adding dropout layers within an autoencoder architecture can be seen as a form of:** (a) Increasing the model's capacity significantly. (b) A regularization technique, similar to denoising, by forcing the network to learn more robust representations that are not overly reliant on specific neurons. (c) A method to ensure perfect reconstruction of the input. (d) A way to reduce the number of training epochs needed.

**Answer(s): (b)** **Explanation:** Dropout randomly sets a fraction of neuron activations to zero during training. In an autoencoder, this acts as a form of noise or corruption, forcing the network to learn to reconstruct the input even with incomplete information, similar in spirit to denoising autoencoders, and helps in learning more robust rep

title: Untitled 2
heading: Deep Learning - Lecture 8 Quiz
text:
form of noise or corruption, forcing the network to learn to reconstruct the input even with incomplete information, similar in spirit to denoising autoencoders, and helps in learning more robust representations. The lecture shows dropout being added to create a "denoising autoencoder with dropout".

title: Untitled 5
heading: ROOT
text:
f you're asked "What pipelines do you have?" in your presentation, you can describe your GitLab CI/CD pipeline by highlighting its key characteristics and flow. Here's a good way to summarize it, based on what we've built (`.gitlab-ci.yml` from artifact `gitlab_ci_yml_01`):

---

**"For this project, we've implemented a comprehensive CI/CD pipeline using GitLab CI/CD that automates the lifecycle of our two microservices (Service A and Service B) from testing through to deployment and branch promotions. Here's a breakdown of its main capabilities and flow:"**

1. **Triggering & Workflow:**
    
    - "The pipeline is designed to run automatically for various Git events. We have a global `workflow: rule: when: always` to initiate a pipeline, with job-level `rules:` to control what runs when."
    - "Specifically, jobs are configured to run on:
        - Pushes to our main development branch (`master-integration`), our staging branch (`pre-production`), and our release branch (`production`).
        - When Merge Requests are created or updated targeting these key branches.
        - When Git tags (like `v1.1.0`) are pushed, especially for triggering production deployments.
        - On schedules: a nightly schedule for `master-integration` and a weekly schedule for `pre-production` to handle automated promotions."
2. **Core Automated Quality & Build Stages (run on relevant branches/MRs/tags):**
    
    - "**Lint Stage:** The pipeline starts with a `lint` stage where `flake8` checks our Python code for style and syntax errors for both services. This helps catch issues very early."
    - "**Test Stage:** If linting passes, the `test` stage runs. This includes:
        - Unit tests for Service A and Service B.
        - Integration tests for Service A and Service B.

title: Untitled 5
heading: ROOT
text:
ly."
    - "**Test Stage:** If linting passes, the `test` stage runs. This includes:
        - Unit tests for Service A and Service B.
        - Integration tests for Service A and Service B.
        - These are executed using `make` targets which utilize `pytest`. We generate JUnit XML reports for visibility in GitLab."
    - "**Build & Push Images Stage:** After successful tests, this stage builds Docker images for Service A and Service B using their respective Dockerfiles and `make` targets. The images are dynamically tagged (with the Git tag, branch slug, or commit SHA, plus `:latest`) and pushed to our project's private GitLab Container Registry."
    - "**Scan Images Stage:** Once images are in the registry, we use Trivy to scan them for known security vulnerabilities (focusing on HIGH and CRITICAL). The results are available as artifacts and can be integrated with GitLab's security dashboards."
3. **Deployment Stages (to AWS VMs):**
    
    - "**Deploy Infrastructure Stage (`apply_terraform_infra` job):** This job, often triggered manually for `master-integration` or automatically by a `production` tag, runs `make tf_apply`. This uses Terraform to provision or update our AWS infrastructure (VPC, EC2 instances, security groups, basic CloudWatch monitoring). It outputs the VM IPs as an artifact."
    - "**Deploy Services Stage (`deploy_apps_to_vms` job):** Following successful infrastructure setup and image builds, this job (also typically manual for `master-integration` or auto for `production` tags) deploys our services. It:
        1. Retrieves the VM IPs from the Terraform output artifact.
        2. Uses `make setup_all_servers` to run `server_setup.sh` on the VMs (installing Docker, etc.) via SSH.
        3. Uses `make deploy_all_vms` to copy service-specifi

title: Untitled 5
heading: ROOT
text:
Terraform output artifact.
        2. Uses `make setup_all_servers` to run `server_setup.sh` on the VMs (installing Docker, etc.) via SSH.
        3. Uses `make deploy_all_vms` to copy service-specific `docker-compose.deploy.yml` files to the VMs and then, via SSH, runs `docker login` (relying on pre-authentication on VMs for this project's manual deployments, or using tokens for full CI automation), `docker compose pull`, and `docker compose up -d` to start the services using the images from our GitLab registry."
4. **Post-Deployment Validation (`smoke_test_deployment` stage):**
    
    - "**Smoke Test Deployed VMs Job:** After services are deployed to the VMs, this job (usually triggered manually) runs our `scripts/smoke_test.py` script. It uses the VM IPs (from the Terraform artifact) to target the live services and perform basic end-to-end checks."
5. **Automated Promotion Stages (Scheduled):**
    
    - "**Promote to Pre-production:** A nightly scheduled job runs on the `master-integration` branch. If all tests, builds, and scans pass, it automatically merges `master-integration` into our `pre-production` branch."
    - "**Promote to Production:** A weekly scheduled job runs on the `pre-production` branch. If all its checks pass (tests, builds, scans run against `pre-production`), it automatically merges `pre-production` into our `production` branch."
    - "These merges use a `CI_PUSH_TOKEN` for authentication."

**In summary, you could say:** "We have a multi-stage GitLab CI/CD pipeline that automates linting, testing, Docker image building and scanning, and provides mechanisms for deploying both infrastructure (via Terraform) and applications (via Docker Compose on EC2) to AWS. It also includes automated, scheduled promotions between our key Git branches (`mas

title: Untitled 5
heading: ROOT
text:
es mechanisms for deploying both infrastructure (via Terraform) and applications (via Docker Compose on EC2) to AWS. It also includes automated, scheduled promotions between our key Git branches (`master-integration` to `pre-production`, and `pre-production` to `production`) to ensure a consistent and controlled flow of changes towards our production environment."

This explanation covers the "what" and the "why" of your pipeline's structure and key functionalities.

title: Untitled 6
heading: Detailed Explanation of Your `.gitlab-ci.yml` Pipeline
text: This document breaks down the structure and functionality of the `.gitlab-ci.yml` file for the "Multi-Service Application Deployment Pipeline" project.

title: Untitled 6
text:
workflow:
  rules:
    - when: always
```

- **Purpose:** The `workflow:` keyword globally controls whether or not a new pipeline is created for different types of events (pushes, merge requests, schedules, etc.).
    
- **`rules: - when: always`**: This is the simplest workflow rule. It means: "For any event that could trigger a pipeline (like a `git push`, a new merge request, a scheduled run, or a tag push), **always create a new pipeline instance**."
    
- **Rationale:** While the pipeline is always created, the decision of whether individual _jobs_ within that pipeline actually run is then delegated to the `rules:` section defined within each job (or inherited via anchors like `.&default_rules`). This provides immediate visibility that CI has been triggered, while still allowing fine-grained control over job execution.

title: Untitled 6
text:
stages:
  - test
  - build_and_push_images
  - scan_images
  - deploy_infrastructure
  - deploy_services
  - smoke_test_deployment
  - promote_to_preprod
  - promote_to_production
```

- **Purpose:** The `stages:` keyword defines the different phases of your pipeline and their execution order. Jobs assigned to earlier stages must complete successfully (unless marked with `allow_failure: true`) before any jobs in subsequent stages can begin.
    
- **Order & Logic:**
    
    1. **`test`**: Runs automated tests. Catches bugs early.
        
    2. **`build_and_push_images`**: If tests pass, Docker images are built and pushed.
        
    3. **`scan_images`**: Security scans are performed on the newly built images.
        
    4. **`deploy_infrastructure`**: (Often manual) Terraform provisions/updates AWS infrastructure.
        
    5. **`deploy_services`**: (Often manual) Applications are deployed to the VMs.
        
    6. **`smoke_test_deployment`**: Quick end-to-end check of the deployed services.
        
    7. **`promote_to_preprod`**: Scheduled job to merge `master-integration` to `pre-production`.
        
    8. **`promote_to_production`**: Scheduled job to merge `pre-production` to `production`.
        
- **Parallelism:** Jobs within the _same_ stage can run in parallel if enough GitLab Runners are available.

title: Untitled 6
text:
variables:
  SERVICE_A_IMAGE_NAME: "${CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE}/service-a"
  SERVICE_B_IMAGE_NAME: "${CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE}/service-b"
  IMAGE_TAG: ${CI_COMMIT_TAG:-${CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG:-${CI_COMMIT_SHORT_SHA}}}
  SERVICE_A_DIR: service_a
  SERVICE_B_DIR: service_b
  VENV_A: "${CI_PROJECT_DIR}/${SERVICE_A_DIR}/venv"
  VENV_B: "${CI_PROJECT_DIR}/${SERVICE_B_DIR}/venv"
  DOCKER_DRIVER: overlay2
  DOCKER_TLS_CERTDIR: "" 
  GIT_STRATEGY: clone
  TF_DIR: "${CI_PROJECT_DIR}/infrastructure/aws" 
  TF_OUTPUTS_FILE: "${TF_DIR}/tf_outputs.json" 
```

- **Purpose:** Defines variables that are available to all jobs in the pipeline by default.
    
- **Key Variables:**
    
    - `SERVICE_A_IMAGE_NAME`, `SERVICE_B_IMAGE_NAME`: Uses the GitLab predefined variable `CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE` (your project's container registry URL) to construct the full image names.
        
    - `IMAGE_TAG`: A robust definition for the Docker image tag:
        
        1. Uses `CI_COMMIT_TAG` if a Git tag is being pushed.
            
        2. Otherwise, uses `CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG` (the branch name, made URL-safe).
            
        3. As a final fallback (e.g., for detached HEAD commits not directly on a branch), uses CI_COMMIT_SHORT_SHA.
            
            This variable is then used by make targets for building and pushing images.
            
    - `SERVICE_A_DIR`, `VENV_A`, etc.: Define relative paths using `CI_PROJECT_DIR` (the root of the cloned repo on the runner) for consistency, especially for caching and `Makefile` operations.
        
    - `DOCKER_DRIVER: overlay2`, `DOCKER_TLS_CERTDIR: ""`: Standard configuration for the Docker-in-Docker (`dind`) service. Setting `DOCKER_TLS_CERTDIR: ""` disables TLS verification between the Docker client (in the job's main container) and the `dind` service, whi

title: Untitled 6
text:
configuration for the Docker-in-Docker (`dind`) service. Setting `DOCKER_TLS_CERTDIR: ""` disables TLS verification between the Docker client (in the job's main container) and the `dind` service, which simplifies setup on shared runners that might not have the `/certs` directory mounted correctly.
        
    - `GIT_STRATEGY: clone`: Ensures a full, clean Git clone for each job, which is more reliable for Git operations like `git describe` (used in your `Makefile` for local `IMAGE_TAG` determination) or merge operations.
        
    - `TF_DIR`, `TF_OUTPUTS_FILE`: Standardize paths for Terraform operations and the output artifact file.

title: Untitled 6
heading: 3. YAML Anchors & Defaults
text:
- **Purpose:** Anchors (`&anchor_name`) and aliases (`*anchor_name`) are YAML features that allow you to define a block of configuration once and reuse it (merge it using `<<: *anchor_name`) in multiple places. This keeps your CI file DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself).
    
- **`.default_rules: &default_rules`**:
    
    ```
    .default_rules: &default_rules
      rules:
        - if: '$CI_PIPELINE_SOURCE == "schedule" && ($CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == "master-integration" || $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == "pre-production")'
        - if: '$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH =~ /^(master-integration|pre-production|production)$/ || $CI_COMMIT_TAG'
        - if: '$CI_MERGE_REQUEST_TARGET_BRANCH_NAME =~ /^(master-integration|pre-production|production)$/'
        - if: '$CI_PIPELINE_SOURCE != "schedule"' 
          when: on_success 
    ```
    
    - **Rationale:** Defines a common set of conditions for when most `test`, `build`, and `scan` jobs should run. It covers:
        
        1. Scheduled pipelines on `master-integration` or `pre-production`.
            
        2. Pushes to `master-integration`, `pre-production`, `production`, or any Git tag.
            
        3. Merge Requests targeting `master-integration`, `pre-production`, or `production`.
            
        4. A fallback rule: for any other pipeline trigger that isn't a schedule (like a push to a feature branch or an MR to a feature branch), run the job (`when: on_success` is implied if not specified, meaning it runs if previous stages pass).
            
- **`default: image: python:3.11`**:
    
    - **Rationale:** Sets `python:3.11` (a full Debian-based image) as the default Docker image for all jobs unless a job specifies its own `image:`. This image includes `make`, `python3`, and `pip3`, which are needed for many of your `Makefile` targ

title: Untitled 6
heading: 3. YAML Anchors & Defaults
text:
bian-based image) as the default Docker image for all jobs unless a job specifies its own `image:`. This image includes `make`, `python3`, and `pip3`, which are needed for many of your `Makefile` targets and Python-based scripts.
        
- **`.python_cache: &python_cache`**:
    
    ```
    .python_cache: &python_cache
      cache:
        key:
          files: [ "${SERVICE_A_DIR}/requirements.txt", "${SERVICE_B_DIR}/requirements.txt" ]
          prefix: ${CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG}-${CI_JOB_NAME} 
        paths: [ ".cache/pip", "${VENV_A}/", "${VENV_B}/" ]
        policy: pull-push
    ```
    
    - **Rationale:** Defines a caching strategy for Python dependencies to speed up jobs.
        
        - `key:files:`: The cache is specific to the contents of your `requirements.txt` files. If they change, a new cache is created.
            
        - `prefix:`: Adds the branch/tag slug and job name to the cache key for more specificity, helping avoid cache collisions between different branches or jobs that might have slightly different dependency needs or venv states.
            
        - `paths:`: Caches `pip`'s download directory and the virtual environment directories created by your `make install_service_x` targets.
            
        - `policy: pull-push`: The runner tries to download (pull) the cache at the start of the job and uploads (pushes) it at the end if the job succeeds.

title: Untitled 6
heading: 4. `test` Stage Jobs
text:
```
unit_tests_service_a:
  stage: test
  script:
    - "make install_service_a"
    - "make unit_test_a"
  artifacts:
    when: always
    reports:
      junit: service_a/junit-report-unit.xml
  <<: *default_rules
  <<: *python_cache

title: Untitled 6
heading: ... (similar for unit_tests_service_b, integration_tests_service_a, integration_tests_service_b) ...
text:
```

- **Purpose:** To run automated tests for each service.
    
- **Structure:** Separate jobs for unit and integration tests for both Service A and Service B, allowing them to run in parallel.
    
- **`script:`**: Executes `make` targets.
    
    - `make install_service_x`: Sets up the Python virtual environment and installs dependencies (leveraging the cache defined in `.&python_cache`).
        
    - `make unit_test_x` / `make integration_test_x`: Runs `pytest` via the Makefile. `PYTHONPATH` is handled within the Makefile targets to ensure modules are found.
        
- **`artifacts:reports:junit:`**: Specifies that the job produces a JUnit XML test report (e.g., `service_a/junit-report-unit.xml`). GitLab can parse these to display test results in Merge Requests and pipeline views. `when: always` ensures reports are uploaded even if tests fail.
    
- **`<<: *default_rules` and `<<: *python_cache`**: Inherits the common rules for when to run and the Python caching configuration.

title: Untitled 6
heading: 5. `build_and_push_images` Stage Jobs
text:
```
.build_push_template: &build_push_job_definition # Corrected anchor name
  stage: build_and_push_images
  image: docker:latest
  services: [ "docker:dind" ]
  variables: 
    FINAL_IMAGE_TAG: "" # Job-local variable, set in before_script
  before_script:
    - 'apk add --no-cache make bash'
    - | # Multi-line script to robustly set FINAL_IMAGE_TAG
      if [ -n "$CI_COMMIT_TAG" ]; then FINAL_IMAGE_TAG_TEMP="$CI_COMMIT_TAG"; ... fi
      export FINAL_IMAGE_TAG="$FINAL_IMAGE_TAG_TEMP" 
    - 'echo "Docker tag resolved to: ${FINAL_IMAGE_TAG}"'
    - 'echo "$CI_REGISTRY_PASSWORD" | docker login ... "$CI_REGISTRY"'
    - 'export GITLAB_REGISTRY_PREFIX="$CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE"'
  <<: *default_rules # Inherits common run rules
  needs: # Ensures tests pass before building
    - unit_tests_service_a
    - unit_tests_service_b
    - integration_tests_service_a
    - integration_tests_service_b

build_push_service_a_image:
  <<: *build_push_job_definition # Use the correct anchor
  script:
    - make build_push_service_a IMAGE_TAG="${FINAL_IMAGE_TAG}"

title: Untitled 6
heading: ... (similar for build_push_service_b_image) ...
text:
```

- **Purpose:** To build Docker images and push them to the GitLab Container Registry.
    
- **`image: docker:latest` & `services: [ "docker:dind" ]`**: Uses Docker-in-Docker, allowing `docker` commands to be run inside the CI job.
    
- **`variables: FINAL_IMAGE_TAG: ""`**: Declares a job-local variable.
    
- **`before_script`**:
    
    - Installs `make` and `bash` (as `docker:latest` is Alpine-based).
        
    - **Calculates and exports `FINAL_IMAGE_TAG`**: This robustly determines the image tag based on `CI_COMMIT_TAG`, `CI_COMMIT_REF_SLUG`, or `CI_COMMIT_SHORT_SHA`. It also sanitizes the tag (e.g., prepends "r-" if it starts with a hyphen).
        
    - Logs into the GitLab Container Registry (`$CI_REGISTRY`) using predefined secure CI variables (`$CI_REGISTRY_USER`, `$CI_REGISTRY_PASSWORD`).
        
    - Exports `GITLAB_REGISTRY_PREFIX` (as `$CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE`) for the `Makefile` to use.
        
- **`script:`**: Calls `make build_push_service_x IMAGE_TAG="${FINAL_IMAGE_TAG}"`. The `Makefile` target handles `docker build` (tagging with `FINAL_IMAGE_TAG` from CI and also as `:latest`) and `docker push` for both tags.
    
- **`needs:`**: Specifies that these build jobs depend on the successful completion of all test jobs.

title: Untitled 6
heading: 6. `scan_images` Stage Jobs
text:
```
.scan_image_template: &scan_image_job # Corrected anchor name
  stage: scan_images
  image:
    name: aquasec/trivy:latest
    entrypoint: [ "" ]
  variables: 
    FINAL_IMAGE_TAG: ""
  before_script:
    - 'trivy --version'
    - | # Re-calculate FINAL_IMAGE_TAG for this job's environment
      if [ -n "$CI_COMMIT_TAG" ]; then FINAL_IMAGE_TAG_TEMP="$CI_COMMIT_TAG"; ... fi
      export FINAL_IMAGE_TAG="$FINAL_IMAGE_TAG_TEMP"
    - 'echo "Scanning image tag: ${FINAL_IMAGE_TAG}"'
  allow_failure: true 
  needs: [ build_push_service_a_image, build_push_service_b_image ]
  <<: *default_rules

scan_service_a_image:
  <<: *scan_image_job # Use the correct anchor
  script:
    - "export TRIVY_USERNAME=$CI_REGISTRY_USER"
    - "export TRIVY_PASSWORD=$CI_REGISTRY_PASSWORD"
    - "trivy image --exit-code 0 --ignore-unfixed --severity HIGH,CRITICAL ${SERVICE_A_IMAGE_NAME}:${FINAL_IMAGE_TAG}"
    - "trivy image --ignore-unfixed --format template --template 'gitlab.tpl' -o gl-container-scanning-report-a.json ${SERVICE_A_IMAGE_NAME}:${FINAL_IMAGE_TAG}"
  artifacts: { reports: { container_scanning: gl-container-scanning-report-a.json } }

title: Untitled 6
heading: ... (similar for scan_service_b_image) ...
text:
```

- **Purpose:** To scan the built Docker images for known vulnerabilities.
    
- **`image: name: aquasec/trivy:latest entrypoint: [""]`**: Uses the official Trivy image and overrides its entrypoint to allow general shell commands in `before_script` before running `trivy` itself.
    
- **`before_script`**: Calculates `FINAL_IMAGE_TAG` again (as each job is a fresh environment).
    
- **`allow_failure: true`**: Currently set so vulnerabilities don't block the pipeline. This should be made stricter (e.g., `false` or use Trivy's `--exit-code 1` for certain severities) once the process is stable.
    
- **`needs:`**: Depends on the images being successfully built and pushed.
    
- **`script:`**:
    
    - Exports `TRIVY_USERNAME` and `TRIVY_PASSWORD` (using `CI_REGISTRY_USER` and `CI_REGISTRY_PASSWORD`) to allow Trivy to authenticate and pull images from your private GitLab Container Registry.
        
    - Runs `trivy image ...` to scan for `HIGH,CRITICAL` vulnerabilities.
        
    - Runs `trivy image ...` again to generate a `gl-container-scanning-report-x.json` file using the `gitlab.tpl` template for integration with GitLab's security dashboards.
        
- **`artifacts:reports:container_scanning`**: Uploads the Trivy report for GitLab UI integration.

title: Untitled 6
heading: 7. `deploy_infrastructure` Stage Job
text:
```
apply_terraform_infra:
  stage: deploy_infrastructure
  image:
    name: hashicorp/terraform:latest 
    entrypoint: [ "" ]
  before_script:
    - 'apk add --no-cache make bash' 
    # 'cd "${TF_DIR}"' and 'terraform init' are now handled by the make target
  script:
    - "echo 'Running make tf_apply (which includes init, apply, and outputs)...'"
    - "make tf_apply" 
  artifacts:
    paths: [ "${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}" ] 
    expire_in: 1 day 
    when: on_success
  rules: # Defines when this job runs (e.g., manual on master-integration, auto on prod tags)
    # ... (rules as defined previously) ...
```

- **Purpose:** To provision or update your AWS infrastructure using Terraform.
    
- **`image: hashicorp/terraform:latest`**: Uses the official Terraform image.
    
- **`before_script`**: Installs `make` and `bash`. **AWS credentials (`AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID`, `AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY`, `AWS_DEFAULT_REGION`) and any `TF_VAR_...` variables must be configured as secure CI/CD variables in GitLab.**
    
- **`script:`**: Calls `make tf_apply`. Your `Makefile` target `tf_apply` is responsible for `cd`ing into the Terraform directory, running `terraform init`, `terraform apply -auto-approve`, and then `make tf_outputs` (which saves outputs like VM IPs to `${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}`).
    
- **`artifacts:paths:`**: Saves the `${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}` (e.g., `infrastructure/aws/tf_outputs.json`) so subsequent jobs can use the VM IPs.
    
- **`rules:`**: Controls when this job runs (e.g., manually on `master-integration` non-schedule pushes, automatically on `production` tags, manually for MRs targeting `master-integration`).

title: Untitled 6
heading: 8. `deploy_services` Stage Job
text:
```
deploy_apps_to_vms:
  stage: deploy_services
  image: alpine:latest
  variables: 
    FINAL_IMAGE_TAG: ""
  before_script:
    - 'apk add --no-cache openssh-client make bash jq'
    - | # Calculate FINAL_IMAGE_TAG
      if [ -n "$CI_COMMIT_TAG" ]; then FINAL_IMAGE_TAG_TEMP="$CI_COMMIT_TAG"; ... fi
      export FINAL_IMAGE_TAG="$FINAL_IMAGE_TAG_TEMP"
    - 'export VM_SERVICE_A_IP=$(jq -r ".service_a_vm_public_ip.value" "${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}")' # Get IPs from artifact
    - 'export VM_SERVICE_B_IP=$(jq -r ".service_b_vm_public_ip.value" "${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}")'
    - 'mkdir -p ~/.ssh && echo "${SSH_PRIVATE_KEY}" > ~/.ssh/id_rsa_gitlab_ci && chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_rsa_gitlab_ci' # Setup SSH key
  script:
    # Pass variables to make for server setup and deployment
    - 'SERVICE_A_VM_IP="$VM_SERVICE_A_IP" ... make setup_all_servers'
    - 'SERVICE_A_VM_IP="$VM_SERVICE_A_IP" ... IMAGE_TAG="$FINAL_IMAGE_TAG" make deploy_all_vms'
  rules: # Controls when this job runs
    # ...
  needs: [ build_push_service_a_image, build_push_service_b_image, apply_terraform_infra ] # Depends on images and infra
```

- **Purpose:** To deploy your containerized applications to the AWS VMs.
    
- **`image: alpine:latest`**: A small base image; installs needed tools (`openssh-client`, `make`, `bash`, `jq`).
    
- **`needs:`**: Depends on images being built/pushed and infrastructure being ready (and gets the `tf_outputs.json` artifact from `apply_terraform_infra`).
    
- **`before_script`**:
    
    - Calculates `FINAL_IMAGE_TAG`.
        
    - Installs necessary tools.
        
    - Sets up the SSH private key (from the `SSH_PRIVATE_KEY` CI/CD variable) for connecting to VMs.
        
    - Uses `jq` to parse the VM IPs from the `${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}` artifact and exports them as `VM_SERVICE_A

title: Untitled 6
heading: 8. `deploy_services` Stage Job
text:
SSH private key (from the `SSH_PRIVATE_KEY` CI/CD variable) for connecting to VMs.
        
    - Uses `jq` to parse the VM IPs from the `${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}` artifact and exports them as `VM_SERVICE_A_IP` and `VM_SERVICE_B_IP`.
        
- **`script:`**:
    
    - Calls `make setup_all_servers`, passing the VM IPs and SSH key path as environment variables to `make`.
        
    - Calls `make deploy_all_vms`, passing VM IPs, SSH key path, `GITLAB_REGISTRY_PREFIX` (as `$CI_REGISTRY_IMAGE`), and the `FINAL_IMAGE_TAG` to `make`. The `Makefile` targets then use these to `scp` `docker-compose.deploy.yml` files and run `docker compose` commands on the VMs. (This assumes VMs are pre-authenticated to the GitLab registry for `docker login` on the VM to succeed non-interactively).
        
- **`rules:`**: Defines when this job runs (e.g., manually on `master-integration`, auto on `production` tags, manually for MRs).

title: Untitled 6
heading: 9. `smoke_test_deployment` Stage Job
text:
```
smoke_test_deployed_vms:
  stage: smoke_test_deployment
  # ...
  before_script:
    - 'apt-get update -y && apt-get install -y python3-pip jq' 
    - 'pip3 install httpx'
    - 'export VM_SERVICE_A_IP=$(jq -r ".service_a_vm_public_ip.value" "${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}")' # Get IPs
    - 'export VM_SERVICE_B_IP=$(jq -r ".service_b_vm_public_ip.value" "${TF_OUTPUTS_FILE}")'
  script:
    - 'export SMOKE_TEST_SERVICE_A_URL="http://${VM_SERVICE_A_IP}:8000"' # Set URLs for script
    - 'export SMOKE_TEST_SERVICE_B_URL="http://${VM_SERVICE_B_IP}:8001"'
    - "python3 scripts/smoke_test.py"
  rules: # Controls when this job runs (e.g., manual after deployments)
    # ...
  needs: [ deploy_apps_to_vms, apply_terraform_infra ] # Depends on deployment and infra outputs
```

- **Purpose:** To run end-to-end smoke tests against the services deployed on the VMs.
    
- **`needs:`**: Depends on `deploy_apps_to_vms` (to ensure services are deployed) and `apply_terraform_infra` (to get the `tf_outputs.json` artifact with VM IPs).
    
- **`before_script`**: Installs `httpx` and `jq`, reads VM IPs from the artifact.
    
- **`script:`**: Exports `SMOKE_TEST_SERVICE_A_URL` and `SMOKE_TEST_SERVICE_B_URL` using the VM IPs, then runs `python3 scripts/smoke_test.py`.
    
- **`rules:`**: Typically manual, run after a deployment to verify its health.

title: Untitled 6
heading: 10. Promotion Stages (`promote_to_preprod`, `promote_to_production`)
text:
```
merge_to_preproduction:
  stage: promote_to_preprod
  image: name: alpine/git entrypoint: [""]
  before_script: # Configures git and auth using CI_PUSH_TOKEN
    # ...
  script: # Fetches branches, resets local, merges master-integration to pre-production, pushes pre-production
    # ...
  rules:
    - if: '$CI_PIPELINE_SOURCE == "schedule" && $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == "master-integration"'
      when: on_success
  needs: # Depends on all prior quality gates for master-integration
    # ... list of test, build, scan jobs ...

title: Untitled 6
heading: merge_to_production is similar, but for pre-production -> production on a weekly schedule.
text:
```

- **Purpose:** To automate the merging of code between long-lived environment branches.
    
- **`image: alpine/git` with `entrypoint: [""]`**: Uses a Git-enabled image and allows shell commands.
    
- **`before_script`**: Configures `git user.email`, `user.name`, and sets the remote URL to use `https://gitlab-ci-token:${CI_PUSH_TOKEN}@...` for authentication. `CI_PUSH_TOKEN` must be a Project Access Token with `write_repository` scope, stored as a secure CI/CD variable.
    
- **`script:`**: Contains `git` commands to fetch the relevant branches, ensure the local target branch is up-to-date with its remote counterpart (`git reset --hard origin/...`), perform a non-fast-forward merge (`git merge --no-ff --no-edit origin/...`), and then push the target branch. If the merge fails (e.g., conflicts), the job exits with an error.
    
- **`rules:`**: These jobs are triggered by scheduled pipelines on their respective source branches (`master-integration` for pre-prod promotion, `pre-production` for production promotion).
    
- **`needs:`**: They depend on the successful completion of all preceding quality gate jobs (tests, builds, scans) from the _same scheduled pipeline run_ on the source branch.
    

This detailed pipeline structure provides a robust framework for automating the testing, building, scanning, deployment, and promotion of your multi-service application.

title: Untitled 9
heading: ROOT

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: Deep Dive: The Utility Invoice Application
text: This document provides a detailed explanation of the business logic and technical architecture of the Utility Invoice application.

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: The Problem
text: Large companies receive hundreds of utility invoices (electricity, gas) from various suppliers across different countries. Each invoice has a unique format, language, and terminology for charges (e.g., "Grid Fee" vs. "Distribution Cost"). Manually comparing these to optimize costs is slow, inefficient, and error-prone.

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: The Solution
text:
This application automates the analysis by:
1.  **Ingesting** raw invoice files (PDF, Excel).
2.  **Using AI** to extract and understand the data.
3.  **Normalizing** the data by mapping varied terms to a standard set of categories (e.g., mapping both "Grid Fee" and "Distribution Cost" to a single "Delivery Cost" category).
4.  **Presenting** the information in a unified comparison table and a natural language summary, enabling quick and accurate cost analysis.

---

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: 2. High-Level User Interaction Flow

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: 3. Technical Deep Dive
text: Here we expand on each step of the flow, showing what happens in the code.

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: Stage 1: User Initiates Analysis (Frontend)
text:
The user interacts with the `SelectionMenu.tsx` component to upload files and start the process.

	**Code Snippet (`SelectionMenu.tsx`):**
The "Generate" button has an `onClick` handler that triggers the `onRunAnalysis` function passed down from its parent.

```javascript
// In SelectionMenu.tsx
<button
  onClick={handleRunAnalysis}
  disabled={isLoading || !selectedCountry || tempFiles.length === 0}
>
  {isLoading ? 'Generating...' : 'Generate'}
</button>
```

**Flow:**
```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant SelectionMenu as SelectionMenu.tsx
    participant UIAgent as UtilityInvoiceAgent.tsx

    User->>SelectionMenu: 1. Clicks "Generate" button
    activate SelectionMenu
    SelectionMenu->>UIAgent: 2. Calls `onRunAnalysis(files, country, prompts)`
    deactivate SelectionMenu
```

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: Stage 2: Frontend Sends Request

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: Stage 3: Backend Receives and Prepares Data
text:
The backend, built with FastAPI, receives the request. The endpoint defined in `routers/generate_results.py` is triggered. It processes the files for the next step.

**Code Snippet (`routers/generate_results.py`):**
This function reads the asynchronous `UploadFile` objects, gets their byte content, and encodes them into Base64 strings.

```python

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: In routers/generate_results.py
text:
@generate_results_router.post("/invoice-analysis")
async def generate_results(
    files: List[UploadFile] = File(...),
    prompt: str = Form(...),
    # ...
):
    session_files = []
    for file in files:
        file_content = await file.read()
        encoded_string = bytes_to_base64(file_content)
        session_files.append(SessionFile(
            data=encoded_string,
            mime_type=file.content_type,
            file_name=file.filename).model_dump())
    # ... calls the controller
```

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: Stage 4: Backend Calls the Central "Generation Service"
text:
The router delegates the core logic to the `GenerationService` in `controllers/generation_controller.py`. This service is responsible for communicating with the shared, internal "generation service".

**Flow:**
```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant Router as generate_results.py
    participant Controller as generation_controller.py
    participant Client as framework_client.py
    participant GenService as External Generation Service

    Router->>Controller: 1. Calls `generation_service.add_message()`
    activate Controller
    Controller->>Controller: 2. Prepares JSON payload with prompt, files, and model config
    Controller->>Client: 3. Calls `get_generation_response(json_data)`
    
    activate Client
    Client->>GenService: 4. Makes `client.post(url, json)` request
    GenService-->>Client: 5. Returns AI analysis
    deactivate Client
    
    Client-->>Controller: 6. Returns response
    Controller-->>Router: 7. Returns final formatted data
    deactivate Controller
```

**Code Snippet (`controllers/generation_controller.py`):**
This is the exact point where the backend calls the external generation service.

```python

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: In controllers/generation_controller.py
text:
async def get_generation_response(self, json_data: dict) -> Json:
    service_url = settings.generation_service_url
    client = get_framework_client()
    
    # This is the network call to the shared service
    response = await client.post(url=service_url, json=json_data, timeout=1200)
    
    response.raise_for_status()
    return response.json()
```

title: utilitiy invoice business logic
heading: Stage 5: Frontend Renders the Result
text:
Back in `UtilityInvoiceAgent.tsx`, the `fetch` call completes. The component updates its state with the new data, which causes React to re-render the UI.

**Code Snippet (`UtilityInvoiceAgent.tsx`):**
```javascript
// In UtilityInvoiceAgent.tsx (continuation of runAnalysis)
      const data = await res.json();
      // ... logic to split comparison and analysis ...
      setComparison(comparisonText);
      setAiAnalysis(aiAnalysisText);
      setLoading(false);
```

**Flow:**
```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant UIAgent as UtilityInvoiceAgent.tsx
    participant React as React (`useState`)
    participant Results as Results.tsx
    
    UIAgent->>React: 1. `setComparison()` and `setAiAnalysis()` are called
    activate React
    React-->>Results: 2. State change triggers re-render of the Results component with new props
    deactivate React
    
    activate Results
    Results->>Results: 3. Renders the Markdown tables and text
    deactivate Results
```
This final step makes the analysis visible to the user.

title: utility invoice backend security bitfall
heading: ROOT
text:
That's an excellent and crucial question. You've correctly identified that authenticating the user on the frontend is only 
  half the story. The connection to the backend must also be secured to ensure it only accepts requests from authenticated 
  users.

  Upon analyzing the code, I've found a major security pitfall:

  The backend API endpoint is completely unsecured. It does not verify the user's authentication status.

  Here is the breakdown of the issue:

   1. Frontend Authentication: The frontend correctly uses OAuth to get an id_token from Google and stores it in a cookie. This 
      proves the user's identity to the browser.

   2. API Request from Frontend: In apps/utility-invoices-frontend/src/components/UtilityInvoiceAgent.tsx, the fetch call to the 
      backend is made like this:

   1     const res = await fetch(`${BASE_URL}/pp/utility-invoices/api/v1alpha1/invoice-analysis`, {
   2       method: 'POST',
   3       body: formData,
   4     });
      While the browser will automatically send the idToken cookie along with this request, the backend code doesn't do 
  anything with it.

   3. Backend Endpoint Implementation: In apps/utility-invoices-backend/src/routers/generate_results.py, the endpoint is defined 
      as:

```
   1     @generate_results_router.post("/invoice-analysis")
   2     async def generate_results(
   3         files: List[UploadFile] = File(...),
   4         prompt: str = Form(...),
   5         currency_rate: float = Form(...)
   6     ):
   7         # ... analysis logic ...
```
      There is no code here to inspect incoming headers or cookies, validate a token, or check for a user session. The 
  endpoint immediately proceeds to process the request.

  The Impact

  This is a critical vulnerability. It means that anyone on

title: utility invoice backend security bitfall
heading: ROOT
text:
aders or cookies, validate a token, or check for a user session. The 
  endpoint immediately proceeds to process the request.

  The Impact

  This is a critical vulnerability. It means that anyone on the internet who can access the backend URL can call the 
  `/invoice-analysis` endpoint directly, bypassing the frontend login entirely. They can upload files and trigger costly, 
  resource-intensive AI jobs without any authentication.

  How to Fix This

  The connection must be secured by implementing token-based authentication on the backend.

   4. Frontend Change: Modify the fetch call in UtilityInvoiceAgent.tsx to include the id_token in the Authorization header. The 
      browser cookie can serve as the source for this token.


```
   1     // Example modification
   2     const idToken = getCookie('idToken'); // Function to read the cookie
   3     const res = await fetch(URL, {
   4       method: 'POST',
   5       headers: {
   6         'Authorization': `Bearer ${idToken}`
   7       },
   8       body: formData,
   9     });
```
   4. Backend Change: Implement a security dependency in FastAPI that:
       * Requires an Authorization: Bearer token header on the /invoice-analysis endpoint.
       * Validates the received Google id_token to ensure it is authentic, not expired, and was issued for your application.
       * Rejects any request that fails validation with a 401 Unauthorized error.





 but what if the URL is only open to people from Valeo  
 from an authentication and authorization standpoint, it still leaves two significant security gaps:

  5. Lack of Authentication (Knowing Who)

  Even within a trusted network, the backend endpoint remains effectively anonymous. It knows the request is coming from 
  somewhere inside Valeo, but it has no idea

title: utility invoice backend security bitfall
heading: ROOT
text:
of Authentication (Knowing Who)

  Even within a trusted network, the backend endpoint remains effectively anonymous. It knows the request is coming from 
  somewhere inside Valeo, but it has no idea which user or service is making the call.

   * Audit and Accountability: You cannot log which user initiated an analysis. If there is misuse, excessive cost, or an error,
      you have no way of tracing the action back to a specific individual.
   * Malicious Insider/Compromised Account: Any employee or contractor on the Valeo network could potentially find and use this 
     endpoint, even if they aren't authorized for this specific application. More realistically, if an attacker compromises any 
     Valeo employee's machine or credentials, they gain access to the internal network and can then make unauthenticated calls 
     to your backend as if they were a legitimate user.

  2. Lack of Authorization (Knowing What They're Allowed to Do)

  Because the backend doesn't authenticate the user, it cannot perform any authorization.

   * No Granular Access Control: You cannot restrict the use of this tool to a specific group, like the Purchasing department. 
     Anyone on the network who finds the endpoint can use it.
   * No Future Permission Models: If you later decide to add features with different permission levels (e.g., "admin" vs. 
     "user"), you cannot implement this without first authenticating each request to know who the user is and what roles they 
     have.

  Conclusion: Defense in Depth

  Relying only on network security is like having a strong front door to your building but leaving all the apartment doors 
  unlocked. Once someone is inside the building, they can go anywhere.

  The best practice is "Defense in Depth," which means having multiple lay

title: utility invoice backend security bitfall
heading: ROOT
text:
to your building but leaving all the apartment doors 
  unlocked. Once someone is inside the building, they can go anywhere.

  The best practice is "Defense in Depth," which means having multiple layers of security. The network restriction is your 
  first layer. The second, crucial layer is application-level authentication, where every single API request must present a 
  valid token to prove who it's from.
